The 71-year-old won 60.75% of the vote while his nearest rival Kizza Besigye took 35%, the election commission has announced. The 71-year-old, President Yoweri Museveni, has retained his position as the head of Uganda, following a contentious election. The victory has extended his rule into a fourth decade, with this marking his sixth term in office.

The election results saw Museveni securing 60.75% of the vote, while his closest competitor, Kizza Besigye, garnered 35%. This was a significant win for Museveni, who managed to maintain a substantial lead over his main rival. 

However, the election was not without controversy, with Besigye's supporters alleging widespread voter fraud and irregularities. Besigye himself was arrested multiple times during the election period, raising questions about the fairness of the elections. 

Despite these disturbances, international observers have noted that aside from isolated incidents, the elections were generally peaceful. 

The election commission’s announcement has paved the way for Museveni to continue his long-standing rule. Whether this will bring stability or

original:
Palmer expects to be fined by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) for the rule breach during Champions Day. "It was a regrettable error on my part," the veteran trainer admitted, and expects to face financial repercussions after falling foul of BHA's regulations on Champions Day.

The infraction occurred when Palmer, renowned in the horseracing world for his numerous victories, ran an ineligible horse in one of the day's most prestigious races. Despite Palmer's pleas for leniency, citing a simple misunderstanding of the rules, the BHA is committed to maintaining the integrity of the sport.

A spokesperson from the BHA affirmed, "While we appreciate Mr. Palmer's honesty in this matter, a breach in rules cannot be overlooked. Ensuring fair competition for all participants is our utmost priority."

Whilst the exact amount of the fine is yet to be determined, some speculate it could potentially reach into the thousands, significantly affecting Palmer's earnings from Champions Day. Despite the setback, Palmer remains optimistic about his future in the sport, promising to ensure compliance with all BHA regulations going forward.

original: Seamer Abbott, 29, and top-order batsman Rossouw, 27, confirmed their international retirements in January. Rossouw, in his first season in county cricket, refused to say if his hand had been forced by Cricket South Africa. "Maybe, maybe not," he told BBC Sport. "I think that story is one I'm going to tell at a different time." Kolpak contracts allow sportsmen from countries with associate trade agreements with the European Union to be afforded the same right to free movement as EU citizens. They are not classed as overseas players under the terms of their contracts, but they become ineligible to represent their country at international level. Abbott and Rossouw's decisions came before Britain's exit from the European Union and they are among several South Africans to make the switch ahead of the new domestic season. Among the others, all-rounder Simon Harmer has joined Essex,Stiaan van Zyl and David Wiese have moved to Sussex and fast bowler Hardus Viljoen will line up for Derbyshire.

Officials imposed a curfew in several cities, including the capital, in an effort to quell the unrest. Tear gas and live bullets were fired to drive back the mainly Shia Muslim crowds, as they protested against corruption and security failures. original:
Mr Reagan and three others were injured in the shooting outside a hotel in Washington in March 1981. Mr Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity and has lived in a psychiatric hospital since the assassination attempt on the then-president.

Mr Reagan and three others were injured in the shooting outside a hotel in Washington in March 1981. Mr Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity and has lived in a psychiatric hospital since the assassination attempt on the then-president. He opened fire as Ronald Reagan was leaving the Washington Hilton Hotel after a conference, seriously wounding the president and three others. 

The shooting shocked the nation and brought into sharp focus the issue of gun control and mental health. Hinckley, obsessed with actress Jodie Foster and seeking to impress her, was committed to St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington. His release in 2016, after more than three decades, was met with widespread controversy, renewing debates on mental health, gun control, and the adequacy of the insanity defense. The incident remains one of the most notorious in American political history.

original: Envoy Sigrid Kaag was speaking as Syria appeared to miss a Sunday deadline to remove its arsenal from the country. All Syria's chemical weapons were supposed to have been shipped out by February 5th, but a failure to meet this deadline has led to growing international concern. Envoy Sigrid Kaag, who heads the joint mission of the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and the United Nations, voiced her concerns about the delay. She reiterated that the international community is closely watching the situation. "This is not a deadline to be missed lightly," Kaag said. "Every delay increases the risk of these weapons falling into the wrong hands, with unthinkable consequences." As the deadline passed, only around 11% of Syria's chemical arsenal had been removed, according to the OPCW. The international community is calling on Syria to accelerate the process. The delay not only puts the disarmament process at risk but also underscores the complexity and challenges of eliminating Syria's sizable chemical weapons program amidst an ongoing civil war.

"This deadline must not be missed lightly," she said. "Each delay heightens the risk of these weapons falling into dangerous hands, with grave consequences." By the deadline, just around 11% of Syria's chemical weapons had been removed, per the OPCW. The international community urges Syria to speed up this process. original: The Port Talbot-based Specific innovation centre is working on the concept of "buildings as power stations". The project involves Tata Steel, Swansea and Cardiff universities, and firms including BASF and Pilkington. More than half the funding is from the European Union. The technology being developed aims to enable homes, offices, shops and factories to generate, store and use their own solar energy. It involves creating innovative coatings for roofs, walls, steel and glass on buildings which can generate electricity. Scientists are also developing solar air collectors or steel "skins" which create cavities between the heated metal and the building to harness and store solar heat. They hope to create buildings which will not need a gas supply. One industrial unit in Port Talbot has already been generating all its own heat through solar power for the last three years. Kevin Bygate, chief executive of Specific said the potential was to deliver a "game changer" on energy: not only for buildings to become self-sufficient but for surplus energy to be stored and to supply the grid. They were close to reaching a target

Helen Bailey, 51, was found dead in a cess pit at her house in Royston, Hertfordshire, in July 2016. She had been reported missing three months prior, sparking a large-scale manhunt. The renowned author of the Electra Brown series, she was known to have touched the hearts of many young readers worldwide. The gruesome discovery sparked a media frenzy around the usually serene Royston community.

Upon further investigation, the police identified her partner, Ian Stewart, as the primary suspect. The evidence pointed to an intricately planned act, resulting in the arrest and subsequent conviction of Stewart for her murder.

The shocking incident has left the literary world in utter disbelief, and sadness permeates among her readers worldwide. The charity wants 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by civil war to be resettled by the end of the year. Ahead of an anticipated spike in displacement caused by escalating violence, the charity is calling for a significant increase in global resettlement efforts for Syrian refugees. This ambitious target, if met, would mark a considerable improvement in the current state of affairs for the estimated 4.8 million Syrians forced from their homes due to the ongoing conflict. 

The charity's goal is not merely to provide temporary relief for these refugees, but to offer them a chance at rebuilding their lives in a safe and secure environment. These resettlement efforts would involve cooperation and support from governments worldwide. Despite the myriad challenges such a goal presents, the charity remains undeterred, viewing this as an imperative, humanitarian duty.

The charity's appeal comes at a time when the world is grappling with the worst refugee crisis since World War II. With this bold initiative, they hope to bring attention to the plight of Syrian refugees and inspire action on a global scale to address this crisis.

Gabon was selected as host on Wednesday by the Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee, beating rival candidates Ghana and Algeria. "We will prepare meticulously to present a first-class tournament," a Gabonese government spokesperson said, expressing the country's commitment to making the event a resounding success. 

This decision marks a significant win for Gabon, who now holds the responsibility of showcasing African football to the world. Preparation efforts will focus on upgrading infrastructures, enhancing security measures, and improving sporting facilities. The competition is expected to boost Gabon's economy by attracting international tourists and promoting local businesses.

The selection of Gabon as the host has received mixed reactions. While some praise it as an opportunity to spotlight the country's growth and potential, others express concern over its readiness to manage such a large-scale event. Nevertheless, the country is determined to rise to the occasion and deliver a memorable tournament. This event will undoubtedly put Gabon on the global sports map and strengthen unity throughout Africa.

A website polled users as to which country he should tour next, with no restrictions on the nations that could be voted on. There are now almost 160 countries listed in the poll's results, reflecting the global outreach and diversity of the website's audience.

The poll is gaining significant attention, with thousands of people worldwide casting their votes. The leading contenders are currently Japan, Australia, and Italy, demonstrating a varied interest in both Eastern and Western cultures. But less travelled nations such as Bhutan, Malawi, and Uzbekistan are also getting impressive votes, highlighting a thirst for off-beat destinations.

This online poll is an interesting way to perceive global tourism preferences, and it provides insight into the diverse tastes and travel dreams of internet users worldwide. As the poll continues to gather votes, it will be exciting to see which destination eventually takes the lead in this global travel wish-list.

They escaped back through the same hole. Police later found a burned-out vehicle close to the airport. Police are looking for eight men, a prosecutors' spokeswoman said. Caroline De Wolf, of the Antwerp World Diamond Centre, estimated the haul at $50m, saying: "What we are talking about is obviously a gigantic sum." Earlier reports suggested the figure was even higher - with the Belgian state broadcaster reportedly putting it at 350m euros ($468m). AFP quoted an unnamed spokeswoman at the same Antwerp centre calling the robbery "one of the biggest" ever. She said that the diamonds were "rough stones" being transported from Antwerp to Zurich. original:
John McCormack drove for a further 30 miles in the articulated lorry after hitting a vehicle on the A9. Perth Sheriff Court was told there that McCormack, 45, was unaware of the incident due to the size of his vehicle. The incident occurred near the town of Pitlochry in the Scottish Highlands, causing serious damage to the impacted car but leaving its driver uninjured.

The court heard that McCormack only became aware of the accident hours later when he stopped at a service station and noticed the damage to his lorry. McCormack, of Inverness, pleaded guilty to failing to stop and report an accident. Defence solicitor, Mr. David Sinclair argued that McCormack genuinely had no idea that he had hit another car.

The case raises concerns about visibility and awareness for drivers of large vehicles. Sheriff Lindsay Foulis deferred sentence until next month for reports and granted McCormack bail in the meantime. This incident has highlighted the need for improved safety measures and enhanced driver

original: Ben Purdy, 18, was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex about "threatening" messages sent after their break-up. Andrew Bayne, 37, of Trundleys Terrace, and his nephew Michael Bagnall, 22, of Hospital Way - both in Lewisham - were found guilty of the murder. They will be sentenced at the Old Bailey on 20 November. The court heard Mr Purdy and two of his friends - Callum Malone and Jack Walker - confronted Bagnell, and, following the "skirmish" last November, the defendants drove around Bermondsey looking for Mr Purdy. When they found him in Mossington Gardens, Andrew Bayne shot Mr Purdy in the head then pointed the gun towards Callum before making off. Mr Purdy suffered "catastrophic injuries" and died the next day, the court heard. Despite the fact Bagnall had a new girlfriend, prosecutor Crispin Aylett QC told jurors, it still "rankled" that she had moved on and he sent her "threatening messages" by phone and on Facebook. Mr Aylett said: "Ben obviously had enough

Andrew Bayne, 37, from Trundleys Terrace, and his nephew Michael Bagnall, 22, from Hospital Way, both in Lewisham, were convicted of murder. Sentencing is set for 20 November at the Old Bailey. The court learned that Ben and his friends, Callum Malone and Jack Walker, confronted Bagnall, leading to a skirmish last November, after which the defendants searched for Ben around Bermondsey. Upon finding him in Mossington Gardens, Andrew Bayne shot Ben in the head, then aimed the gun at Callum before fleeing. Ben sustained severe injuries and died the next day. Even though Bagnall had a new girlfriend, prosecutor Crispin Aylett QC told the jury that he was still resentful about her moving on and sent threatening messages via phone and Facebook. Mr Aylett said, 'Ben obviously had enough.'

original: Hanjin filed for receivership in South Korea last week after attempts to bail out the indebted company failed. Ports have refused to accept Hanjin cargoes without guarantees that port fees will be paid. However, creditors, banks and the South Korean government are all reluctant to put up the cash. The global economic downturn, fierce competition and falling prices has hit profits across the cargo shipping industry and Hanjin collapsed with debts of about $5.4bn (Â£4.1bn) last month. There are an estimated 89 Hanjin ships out of its 141-vessel fleet in difficulty, and some have been seized by creditors. The ships contain everything from computer parts to perishable food with many of the cargoes destined for the Christmas market in the US and Europe. Samsung Electronics has said it has goods worth about $38m on Hanjin ships in international waters. It is now considering chartering 16 freighter planes to take goods to customers - mostly in the US. Hanjin's main creditors said it would be difficult to accept a request from the court presiding over the company's receivership to give it fresh funds. The state-backed Korea Development Bank said

The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The volcano, one of the country's most active, has seen a significant upsurge in activity in recent months, raising concerns among scientists about a potential major eruption. 

The University of Bristol team, in collaboration with colleagues at the Sakurajima Volcano Research Centre, have been monitoring the volcano closely. They warn that the current increase in activity could potentially lead to a large-scale eruption, threatening the nearby city of Kagoshima and its 600,000 inhabitants.

The researchers' concerns are built on a combination of seismic data, ground deformation and gas emission measurements. In particular, the alarming rate of ground swelling around the volcano indicates a significant increase in magma supply. 

While the local authorities are taking necessary precautions, the situation serves as a reminder of the unpredictable and devastating power of nature. The current escalation at Sakurajima underscores the urgent

original:
The girl, who has Smith-Magenis Syndrome, was arrested four times and twice held overnight in police stations. Her mother complained about her daughter's treatment, igniting a conversation about the handling of individuals with mental health disorders in the criminal justice system.

Smith-Magenis Syndrome is a developmental disorder that can lead to behavioral issues, including temper tantrums and self-harm. In this case, the young girl's interaction with the police was a result of such behaviors. Her mother, however, insists that the police's response was both excessive and inappropriate. 

The arrests have sparked considerable outrage within the community and beyond, highlighting the broader issue of how law enforcement deals with individuals suffering from mental health disorders. Critics argue that police should be better trained to handle such situations, ensuring that individuals with conditions like Smith-Magenis Syndrome are treated fairly and with compassion. 

This case serves as a stark reminder of the dire need for reform within law enforcement, and for a more empathetic approach to policing

original: The Employment and Learning minister, Dr Stephen Farry, has decided to remove a special premium payment of Â£1.1m which it has been getting to compensate for its small scale and specialist status. It has fewer than 1,000 students and an income of Â£4.7m a year. Protesters have said that the removal of the small institution premium, coupled with a general cutback in Department of Employment and Learning (DEL) funding, would mean the college loses 31% of its budget. However, an extra Â£32m for the DEL, revealed in this week's overall budget improves the situation somewhat. The college says the addition of extra money means it would be asked to manage on a budget reduced by 26.5%. That's a slightly better prediction but the principal, Prof Peter Finn, says that is still far too challenging. He accuses Stephen Farry of a blatantly opportunistic decision to force the college to agree to one of the solutions he proposes for the future streamlining of teacher training in Northern Ireland. None of the four options includes St Mary's keeping its current autonomy. It says it is

Nevertheless, a recent budget allocation of an additional Â£32m to the DEL somewhat alleviates the issue. The button would give Google Search users the option to purchase without needing to visit a separate website. The company's chief business officer, Omid Kordestani, confirmed the upcoming roll-out of the "Buy Now" button during a conference. This move is seen as a direct response to combat the increasing dominance of Amazon in the online shopping industry.

The "Buy Now" button will aim to streamline the shopping experience for Google users by allowing purchases to be made directly from the search results page. This presents a major shift in Google's strategy, as it transitions from being solely a search engine to a more integrated service provider. 

Google's decision comes after research indicated that many users start their shopping searches on Amazon rather than Google. By implementing this new feature, the tech giant hopes to reclaim some of this lost market share, enhancing customer convenience and boosting its advertising revenues in the process.

While the exact roll-out date remains undisclosed, Google users worldwide anticipate a streamlined and more efficient online shopping experience. With the competition heating up, this could be a game-changer in the e-commerce sphere.

The "Buy Now" button is designed to simplify shopping by letting users buy directly from Google’s search results page. This represents a significant change in Google's approach, as it evolves from just a search engine to a more integrated service provider.

Google decided on this feature after studies showed many shoppers begin on Amazon instead of Google. By adding this option, Google aims to win back market share, improve user convenience, and increase its advertising revenue.

Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes and businesses were shut when major flooding hit Stoke Newington, Blackheath and Islington. Sadiq Khan, London Mayor, declared a state of emergency as unprecedented rainfall led to the River Thames bursting its banks, creating chaos in the capital. 

Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes and businesses were shut when major flooding hit Stoke Newington, Blackheath and Islington. Sadiq Khan urged residents to follow directives from emergency services and stay away from the affected areas. 

"The safety of Londoners is my top priority. We are doing everything we can to help those affected and prevent further damage," said Khan. 

The London Fire Brigade, along with aid organizations, swiftly responded to the crisis, completing more than 300 rescue missions and delivering essential supplies to stranded residents. 

The flooding has also severely affected transport, with numerous road closures and disruptions in train services. Environmental experts warn that such weather extremes could become more common due to climate change. 

The government has pledged immediate financial support for the affected communities. Recovery and rebuilding efforts are expected to begin as soon as the water levels

original:
The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) said London's poorest children outperformed those in the north. The report is being launched by the government, indicating a stark educational inequality between the two regions.

The research revealed that economically disadvantaged students in the capital are more than twice as likely to achieve good GCSE results compared to their counterparts in northern England. It emerges as a sign of the notable success of the London Challenge Program, initiated in the early 2000s, aimed at improving school performance in the city.

However, this only accentuates the widening educational gap within the country. The IPPR suggested that the government should consider implementing similar initiatives in the north, to improve the quality of education and opportunities for children living in deprived circumstances.

The report also sparked urgent calls for a "Northern Powerhouse" strategy for education, to address the alarming regional disparities and ensure that every child, irrespective of their socio-economic background, has an equal shot at success.

However, this lightly taken comment has sparked a pivotal discussion across the nation about the dangerous influence of misinformation on public discourse and democratic processes.

As part of the broad political landscape, Republicans, Democrats, and Independents alike are wrestling with the challenge of confronting and correcting falsehoods in a time when unverified news spreads rapidly on social media platforms. Experts argue that this widespread dissemination of misinformation threatens the very fabric of informed citizenry, thus eroding the bedrock of democracy.

In response, tech companies and media outlets are taking steps to combat false news, though progress is slow and rife with controversy. Critics argue that the measures may infringe upon free speech rights. Amid this controversy, the responsibility of distinguishing fact from fiction largely falls on individual citizens, underlining the need for enhanced media literacy in the digital age. The news agency's account was suspended and it advised all tweets should be ignored until further notice. The false message said: "Breaking: Two world leaders involved in a violent altercation."

With an immediate suspension upon discovery, the agency moved swiftly to prevent further misinformation. A rogue tweet, falsely alleging a violent altercation between two global leaders, was promptly identified and removed. The source of the misleading information is currently under investigation. 

The agency has since issued a formal apology, assuring the public that its top priority is to report accurate, reliable news. The breach has raised questions about the security measures in place and measures are being taken to reinforce protocols. 

The incident has also triggered a broader conversation on the damage caused by false information spread on social media platforms. The impact of such misinformation can be far-reaching, undermining trust and causing unnecessary alarm. 

Upon resolution, the agency plans to learn from this incident, strengthening its security and maintaining its commitment to journalistic integrity. The public is urged to disregard all tweets

original: Among them was a 17-year-old stopped at Sydney airport a fortnight ago, said Immigration Minister Peter Dutton. Mr Dutton said there was a "growing threat" from Australians attempting to join groups like Islamic State (IS). Special anti-terror teams were installed in Australia's eight international airports in August. The teenager, who was on his way to the conflict in the Middle East, was returned to the custody of his parents while investigations continued, said Mr Dutton. The interception came about a week after two Sydney brothers, aged 16 and 17, were stopped at the same airport on suspicion of attempting to join IS. The brothers, who have not been named, were also returned to their parents. According to Australian media reports, the two students have been allowed to resume their studies at a prestigious Sydney high school, despite concerns being raised by some parents of other students at the school. original:
The deal unveiled by Russia on Thursday to set up four "de-escalation zones" is backed by Turkey and Iran. But the main Syrian opposition group rejects the proposal, claiming it lacks credibility and is likely to further militarize and complicate the Syrian conflict. 

The deal unveiled by Russia on Thursday to set up four "de-escalation zones" is backed by Turkey and Iran. But the main Syrian opposition group, the High Negotiations Committee (HNC), voiced strong reservations, stating that the agreement is more likely to freeze the conflict while allowing continued government attacks on opposition-held areas. 

They express their skepticism over the effectiveness of the "de-escalation zones," citing Russia and Iran's track-record of not honoring previous ceasefires. They fear this deal could be an attempt by Moscow to solidify President Bashar al-Assad's control over swathes of Syria. 

In response, Russia insists that the zones will lead to a cessation of hostilities and improve the humanitarian situation. Despite the opposition, Iran and Turkey - who are important regional powers and stakeholders in the Syrian conflict - have shown their support, contributing to the complex

variant_1: The Financial Conduct Authority noted that these customers generated profits for card providers, leading to minimal incentives for firms to step in. Preliminary findings reveal that while some customers and products faced strong competition, others were neglected. Providers promptly intervened when payments were missed due to unprofitability, but those managing just to keep up did not receive the same attention. Joanna Elson, CEO of Money Advice Trust, emphasized concern for the 1.6 million individuals making only minimum payments across multiple cards. She affirmed the FCA's valid worries as highlighted in the report.

original: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) said London's poorest children outperformed those in the north. The report is being launched by the centre-left think tank in Sheffield. The government said extra funds were being given to early years providers to help children from poorer backgrounds and close the attainment gap. The report has also detailed a number of "tests" or benchmarks for the government's northern powerhouse scheme. Research by the IPPR showed only 47% of children born in the poorest families in the north of England achieved a good level of early years development compared with 59% in London. Its survey also found five northern city-regions combined had almost as many well-qualified individuals (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million) - but the IPPR forecasts demand for skilled workers in the North is set to increase. original: The bodies of backpackers Miss Witheridge, 23, from Norfolk, and Mr Miller, 24, from Jersey, were found on a beach on Koh Tao in September 2014. Burmese bar workers Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Tun were found guilty of the killings in December 2015. An appeal court in Thailand upheld the death sentences handed down to them. Lawyers for the two men now have 30 days to appeal to the Supreme Court - Thailand's final court of appeal. The pair's mothers lodged appeals at Koh Samui court last May over concerns about the judgements, in particular the DNA evidence used in the investigation. "We don't believe the court can say beyond reasonable doubt that Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were responsible for the events which took place in September 2014," said Andy Hall, one of the families' legal advisors. Miss Witheridge, a University of Essex student from Hemsby, and Mr Miller, a civil and structural engineering graduate, were found on a beach

original: Entrants to the annual event have five minutes to tell the biggest and most convincing lie they can. Winner George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria was surprised to win as he was "struggling" with a chest infection. In his story he "ended up bumping into Donald Trump and his wife in an underwater hotel", he said. "It was a tale about building a small submarine out of my dad's old bubble car," he said. "We took the bubble car on a trip to the Isle of Man and we bumped into several famous people in a Scottish submarine made out of shortbread tins. "Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond sold some of these giant shortbread tin submarines to the United States of America." Last year's winner Mike Naylor, known as Monkey Liar, from Wasdale came second. Helen Jordan came third. Previous winners include comedian and television presenter Sue Perkins in 2006. In 2014 one entrant had travelled from Germany to take part. The annual event is held in front of a panel of judges and an audience at the Bridge Inn at Santon Bridge. Politicians

original: The walkout is in protest over the dismissal of two nurses involved in a violent struggle with a patient. Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton were sacked despite using "reasonable force" against the unidentified patient, said the Prison Officers' Association (POA). But Mersey Care Trust, which runs Ashworth, said the evidence meant sacking the pair was its only option. More on this story and other news from Merseyside and Cheshire The dispute at the unit, one of three high security hospitals in England and Wales, began at 07:00 GMT. Steve Gillan, the POA's general secretary, said: "I believe the general public will be outraged and extremely sympathetic to Mr Hilton and Mr Gregson, who were merely responding to a violent act in which the patient had headbutted a colleague and was spitting at staff during the incident. "The actions of restraint were reasonable and the patient came to no harm, unlike the nurses. Whilst there should always be a duty of care towards patients the same must apply to staff." The trust said it was "disappointed"

original: Mr Reagan and three others were injured in the shooting outside a hotel in Washington in March 1981. Mr Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity but was sent for treatment to a Washington hospital. In July, a judge ruled that Mr Hinckley, now 61, was not a danger to himself or the public. Mr Hinckley had already been spending 17 days a month at his mother's home in Virginia under strict conditions. Associated Press reported that he had arrived at her home having been freed on Saturday. original: He threatened to quit the Premier League club within 24 hours if the name change bid failed, and the Football Association turned it down in April. "When I say something, I mean it," the 75-year-old Egyptian said on Thursday. He added that the club had been put up for sale 22 hours after the FA's decision five months ago. Allam said that an appeal was being lodged against the name change rejection with the Court of Arbitration for Sport. "We stated earlier this year that the club would be for sale should our attempt to globally promote Hull Tigers as a brand name and as a playing name be blocked," he said. "As a consequence of the FA decision on 9 April, I announced on 10 April, within 22 hours, that Hull City is for sale." original: The company behind the abattoir in Haverfordwest, Emcol 2008 Ltd, collapsed in January 2016 with debts of £660,000 to more than 230 creditors. One director said it was due to escalating costs and being owed money. Newport dairy farmer John Sollis called it a "disaster" for people in the area who were owed money. Documents lodged on the Companies House website show one livestock trader is owed in excess of £107,000, while others are owed significant five figure sums. In his report, liquidator Gary Stones said any payments to unsecured creditors were "totally dependent on the collection of the Irish book debt". The report indicated almost £470,000 was owed to Emcol by an Irish firm. Mr Sollis, who is owed almost £15,000 by Emcol, said: "It was a disaster in a sense the amount of money that people have lost in the locality and not now having a local abattoir to move stock to or casualties. BBC News reached out to the rogue Environmental Protection Agency account, @ActualEPAFacts, which said they operate to ensure "factual information about climate change and other scientific research continues to be shared during the Trump administration." They identified as three EPA employees acting after a gag order prevented them from giving interviews related to their research. Media reports suggest the Trump administration tried to limit certain government agencies' communication with the public, including the EPA. original:
Muslim cleric Mehboob Akhtar, of Stoke-on-Trent, was sentenced along with nine others including his wife and daughter. They were found guilty of a sophisticated benefit fraud scheme, resulting in the embezzlement of over £450,000 of taxpayer’s money. Investigations revealed that the group had submitted fraudulent applications for tax credits and other benefits over a span of five years.

The Stoke Crown Court heard that Akhtar was the mastermind behind the operation that involved his family members and several close friends. Forensic accountants were brought in to unravel the complex web of illegal financial activities, uncovering a calculated and wilful abuse of the system. 

The prosecution said that the money stolen funded a lifestyle far beyond their legitimate means. Despite the severity of the crime, the defendants maintained their innocence throughout the trial. The judge, in his statement, said that their actions were a "deeply regrettable betrayal of trust" and sentenced the group to a combined total of 20 years of imprisonment.

This case serves as a stark reminder of the serious nature of benefit fraud, its impact on society and the dire consequences for those involved

Masai Graham won with the gag: "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The winning joke from Masai Graham was crowned the funniest of this year's Edinburgh Fringe Festival. The punchline, "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart," was met with roaring laughter from the audience, securing Graham's victory. 

Graham, a London-based comedian, is known for his sharp wit and dry delivery. Despite fierce competition from seasoned comics, his heart transplant-themed gag stood out, winning over both the audience and the panel of judges.

This win adds to Graham's impressive comedic resume, which already includes several successful appearances at previous fringe festivals. He has shown time and again his ability to turn everyday situations into clever and unexpected punchlines, delighting audiences with his unique comedic style.

The Fringe Festival, held annually in Scotland's capital, is renowned for showcasing the best in comedy talent. This year was no exception, and Graham's win confirms his status as one of the leading lights in the UK comedy scene.

original: The care at Stafford Hospital left some patients drinking water from vases, it is claimed, and receptionists assessing emergency cases. Julie Bailey, who set up the campaign group Cure the NHS after witnessing her mother's treatment, was made a CBE. Helene Donnelly, a nurse who became a whistleblower, was made an OBE. Figures suggested there were more deaths than would have been expected at Stafford Hospital between 2005 and 2008. Patients needing pain relief either got it late or not at all, leaving them crying out for help, and there were cases where food and drinks were left out of reach. Helene Donnelly worked in the A&E department at the hospital. She raised nearly 100 complaints about the treatment of patients, turned whistleblower and was a key witness at the Stafford Hospital public inquiry. original:
Heading the processions were some of those caught up in the suicide bomb attacks on Belgium's airport and metro station that killed 32 people. Belgian authorities led a solemn march on Thursday, five years after the deadly terror attacks that inflicted deep wounds on the nation's psyche.

Heading the processions were some of those caught up in the suicide bomb attacks on Belgium's airport and metro station that killed 32 people. Belgian officials, survivors, and relatives of the victims came together in a united show of respect and determination to never forget the painful memories of March 22, 2016. The commemoration event started at Zaventem Airport, where two suicide bombers detonated their lethal devices, killing 16 people.

The march then continued to the Maalbeek metro station in central Brussels, where another 16 people were killed when a third bomber detonated his explosives during the morning rush hour. The poignant procession concluded at the heart of the EU district, below the flags of the 28-member bloc – a stark reminder of the indiscriminate nature of terrorism and the unity that binds us in the face of tragedy.

He's also having to get used to the media and laying out his policies - many of which are quite distinct from the previous leader's. Mr. Thomas Granger, the newly appointed leader, is under the spotlight as he outlines his plans for a novel approach to governance.

Granger has already caught the public eye with his efforts to redefine traditional policy structures. His focus on environmental sustainability, economic equity, and digital transformation starkly contrasts his predecessor's conservative approach. Granger's progressive policies have ignited hope in many, while also stirring up controversy among conservatives.

His pledge to reduce carbon emissions by 50% over the next decade has been hailed by environmentalists. Likewise, his commitment to increasing minimum wage and his ambitious plans for digitalising infrastructure have been met with enthusiasm from young voters.

Yet, the new leader isn't without his critics. Many fear his policies might burden the economy. Nonetheless, Granger remains resilient, promising that his policies will drive long-term prosperity.

original: Sales at the company rose to â‚¬34.2bn (Â£28.8bn) in the year to August. The chain opened 12 new stores, which helped total sales to rise 7.1%, but that increase was lower than the 11% growth seen in the previous 12 months. Sales at stores open for more than a year rose 5% - the same as last year. The privately-owned Swedish group said sales in Poland jumped about 20%, making the country its fastest-growing market, while Australia and Canada also performed well. Germany was still the retailer's largest market, closely followed by the United States. Ikea will open its first stores in India and Serbia this year and now has 340 outlets in 28 countries. The European Challenge Tour, known for unearthing golf's up-and-coming stars, is set to be a highlight of an already action-packed week, which also includes the US PGA Championship and the Women's British Open.

The cut, which took the markets by surprise, was the first since 2012, and comes into effect on Saturday. The one-year lending rate has been slashed by a significant percentage as part of a series of measures to boost a slowing economy. Economists predict this bold move may trigger a slew of similar cuts across the globe, potentially heralding a new era of competitive interest rate reductions.

The decision, announced by the Central Bank on Friday, is widely seen as a response to persistent low inflation and weaker-than-expected growth figures. The Bank said the move aims to "ensure the stability of the financial system and foster sustainable economic growth."

Market watchers believe the surprise rate cut could serve as a strong stimulus for the struggling economy, providing much-needed liquidity and encouraging borrowing. The move is expected to boost business confidence and spur investment, which could in turn lead to job creation and increased consumer spending, further stimulating economic growth. However, some analysts caution that the decision could also lead to increased financial risk

original: The 23-year-old Heracles forward claimed he was waiting to finalise a move to the Championship club. Slade insisted there was no truth to the reports but admitted he did have some interest in the player "some time ago". "To my knowledge that's not something we're going to pursue," he said. Netherlands Under-21 international Weghorst began his career with FC Emmen before joining Heracles in 2014. Heracles chairman Jam Smit believed a fee had been agreed with Cardiff for Weghorst, who has also been linked with Celtic. "I think all the forcing and all the speculation surrounding the player appears to be have come from the Netherlands," added Slade. "There was an initial inquiry some time ago. That's all I can say." original: Falcon and Pointer was fined £175,000 for making automated calls about PPI, and Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd was fined £50,000 for asking to speak to people's dead relatives. Both companies claimed the calls were made by a third party. Anne Jones, Assistant Commissioner for Wales, said it sent a "clear message to callous cold-callers". She said: "It increasingly appears from our investigations that Swansea is the UK's cold-call capital. "Companies in the city have been trying to cash in using ruthless business models based on illicit practices to make calls which are at best irksome and at worst distressing." The commissioner (ICO) has taken action against six companies since 2013. Falcon and Pointer had its licence revoked in January 2016 and told the ICO it had stopped making the calls in June 2015 - but an investigation found it made a further two million calls in the following two months. Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd, which sells windows, doors and conservatories, received 168 complaints in six

original:
The Employment and Learning minister, Dr Stephen Farry, has decided to remove a special premium payment of Â£1.1m which it has been annually disbursed to Northern Ireland's universities. The special premium, usually reserved for science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) courses, has been described by Dr Farry as a "disincentive for universities to broaden their curriculum."

This decision arrives amidst a backdrop of continuing funding issues and budget concerns plaguing the higher education sector in Northern Ireland. The minister hopes the removal of this premium will encourage universities to diversify their course offerings, particularly in the arts and humanities.

Critics of Dr Farry's decision argue it could inadvertently damage the prospects of STEM students, whose subjects are often more costly to deliver. However, Dr Farry insists that the general block grant for universities will not be affected and that the institutions would still have sufficient resources to maintain and invest in STEM courses.

The move is consistent with the minister’s previous insistence on a more balanced higher education sector. Whether the change will bring the desired effect in broadening the curriculum remains to be seen.

original: The amnesty applies to offences committed during the political turmoil after Mr Thaksin was ousted in a coup. The lower house passed the controversial bill in the early hours of Friday. It now goes to the Senate. The opposition Democrat Party has warned that the passage of the bill will trigger street protests. It did not take part in the vote, but the bill passed by 310 votes to 0. The bill's passage through the Senate is less certain, reports the BBC South East Asia correspondent Jonathan Head, as half its members are appointed. But this could happen as early as next week and would almost certainly provoke further protests. Advocates of the bill say it will draw a line under the political turmoil that resulted from the military coup in 2006 that removed Mr Thaksin from power, leaving Thailand bitterly divided. This turmoil included the occupation of Bangkok's main airport in 2008 and then two months of street protests in Bangkok in

original: The Korea Space Launch Vehicle-1 (KSLV-1) blasted off from the Naro Space Center at 16:00 (07:00 GMT). Science Minister Lee Ju-ho said the satellite, which will collect climate data, was in its correct orbit. The launch comes weeks after North Korea used its own three-stage rocket to place a satellite into orbit, sparking international criticism. South Korea's 140-tonne rocket, known as Naro, was built in partnership with Russia, which had agreed to work with Seoul for three launch attempts. Analysis: What is driving North Korea's nuclear test plan? Previous launches in 2009 and 2010 failed, and this attempt had been postponed twice for technical reasons. original: Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The Unesco World Heritage Site is made up of some 40,000 large black basalt columns which protrude from the sea. It was the Royal couple's first visit to Northern Ireland's best known tourist attraction. The causeway formed when molten rock was forced up through fissures in the earth to form a lava plateau. original:
The A320 pilot reported seeing a white quadcopter drone "flash past" the aircraft while travelling south of Brookmans Park last August. No one was injured in the incident, but it sparked major concerns about the potential catastrophic risks that drones could pose to commercial flights. 

The A320 pilot reported seeing a white quadcopter drone "flash past" the aircraft while travelling south of Brookmans Park last August. No immediate damage was reported, but air traffic controllers were alerted about the potential hazard. The drone, estimated to be about a meter across, was flying well above the legal altitude limit for unmanned aircraft, at an estimated height of 4,000 feet.

The incident reignited urgent conversations about regulations surrounding drone use, especially the need for stricter enforcement and harsher penalties for those who flout these rules. The Civil Aviation Authority reiterated the importance of responsible drone use, warning drone operators to stick to the designated height and distance limits. The disturbing near-miss underscores the urgent need for comprehensive action to ensure the safe coexistence of drones and manned aircraft in our increasingly crowded skies.

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, which translates as "fuel shortage in a film", became France's top Twitter trend on Monday amid the ongoing fuel crisis. This social media trend saw internet users recasting famous movie scenes in the context of the country's fuel shortage, blending humor and frustration.

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm sparked hundreds of thousands of tweets, reflecting the French public's concern and exasperation over the energy crisis. Twitter users cleverly inserted the issue into famous scenes from films like Mad Max, Titanic, and Back to the Future. One humorous tweet suggested a reimagined Pulp Fiction where John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson's characters argue over who must push their out-of-gas car.

While the hashtag speaks to the French's knack for humor in crises, it underscores a pressing issue. France has been grappling with fuel shortages due to strikes at oil refineries and blockades protesting against government policies. This virtual outcry reflects the public's call for effective solutions to the country's escalating fuel crisis.

"When he explained who he was I thought it was a hoax," Hightown publicity officer Nick Gordon said. "The conversation developed, we got references from people in the game in Zimbabwe and we've talked ever since. It's a real coup for us." original:
A survey of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Fewer than one in 10 took more than "A survey of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Fewer than one in 10 took more than two weeks off to spend time with their newborns, suggesting that workplace cultures and policies may pose a critical barrier to parental involvement in early child care.

The survey, which involved over 1,000 participants across various job sectors, reflected a persistent stigma associated with paternity leave. Many new fathers reported feeling pressured to return to work due to concerns about job security, income stability, and perceptions of traditional gender roles.

The findings highlight a need for a paradigm shift in corporate attitudes towards paternity leave. Experts argue that encouraging fathers to take their full leave can have significant benefits, not only for the child's development and the mother's postpartum recovery but also for the overall productivity and morale of employees. It's time for businesses to reassess their policies and culture and contribute proactively to nurturing an equitable workforce.
variant_1: A survey of employees and managers revealed that 25% of new fathers did not take any paternity leave, and fewer than 10% took more than two weeks off, indicating that workplace culture and policies might hinder early parental involvement in childcare.
variant_2: Research involving over 1,000 employees and managers found that one in four new fathers skipped paternity leave entirely, with less than 10% taking more than a fortnight, pointing to cultural and policy obstacles within workplaces for paternal engagement in newborn care.
variant_3: A study surveying employees and managers found that a quarter of new dads took no paternity leave, and fewer than 10% took over two weeks off, suggesting that work environments and company policies may restrict fathers' early participation in childcare.
variant_4: The survey of more than 1,000 workers across various sectors showed that 25% of new fathers did not use any paternity leave and under one-tenth exceeded two weeks, highlighting cultural and policy barriers to paternal involvement in early child care.
variant_5: Findings from a survey including employees and managers showed that a quarter of new fathers avoided taking paternity leave altogether and less than 10% took more than two weeks, implying that workplace cultures and policies present challenges to fathers caring for newborns.
variant_6: According to a survey conducted among employees and managers, 25% of new fathers didn't take paternity leave, and fewer than 10% took over two weeks, signifying that company attitudes and policies could be a major barrier to fathers' engagement with their newborns.
variant_7: The employee and manager survey found that a quarter of new fathers completely skipped paternity leave and that less than one in ten took more than two weeks off, indicating that workplace culture and rules may restrict fathers’ involvement in early childcare.
variant_8: Survey data from over 1,000 participants spanning various industries reveals that one-quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave, with fewer than 10% taking more than two weeks, uncovering structural and cultural hurdles in the workplace around parental participation.
variant_9: Results from a survey involving employees and managers showed that 25% of new fathers did not take paternity leave at all, and under 10% took more than two weeks, suggesting work culture and policies form a substantial barrier to early childcare involvement by fathers.
variant_10: A survey conducted among employees and managers found a quarter of new fathers declined paternity leave, and fewer than one in ten took over two weeks off, pointing to workplace cultural norms and policies that may impede fathers' early participation in childrearing.

original: Sterling rose 1.86% against the dollar to $1.32.40, and was 1.73% higher against the euro at â‚¬1.19.57. The FTSE 100 share index hit fresh 11-month highs before falling back and closing scarcely changed at 6,680.69, that is a slight fall of 2.17 points or 0.03%. The more UK-focused FTSE 250 index rose 68.75 points, or 0.4%, to 16,775.14. The property sector - which saw a steep sell-off immediately after the Brexit vote - received a boost from Galliford Try. The housebuilder said it still expected full-year profits to be in line with expectations sending its shares up 8.5%. Financial stocks - another victim of the post-referendum sell-off - were also having a better day. Shares in insurer Aviva rose 4.26% while Lloyds Banking Group gained 2.55%. "Theresa May's virtual 'coronation' as prime minister has delivered a boost to the pound as the clouds of uncertainty following the Brexit vote start to disperse," said Neil Wilson,

The Halle Orchestra wants to open a school in Stoke-on-Trent in 2020, for both primary and secondary pupils. The orchestra, known for its renowned musical heritage, is taking this bold step to nurture a new generation of musicians.

The proposed school will be a first-of-its-kind initiative in the region, offering a unique curriculum integrating classical music education with standard academics. The Halle Orchestra aims to provide a platform for youngsters to pursue their passion for music in a formal setting, while also ensuring they excel in other academic areas.

The school plans to have experienced musicians from the orchestra as trainers and mentors for the students. This will give students the rare opportunity to learn directly from professionals who are part of one of the UK's oldest and most respected symphony orchestras.

This initiative is seen as a major boost for Stoke-on-Trent's cultural scene and an excellent opportunity for budding musicians in the region. The school will also offer scholarships for talented students, further emphasizing its commitment to fostering

The investment is backed by nearly £15m from the Welsh government, with production due to start in late 2018. Economy Minister Edwina Hart said the funding is part of an ambitious project aiming to boost the region's economy and create new job opportunities. This investment will channel into the manufacturing sector, which is earmarked as a key growth area. 

Hart emphasized the importance of the manufacturing industry, stating it contributes significantly to the Welsh economy. She believes this investment is a testament to the government's commitment to promote economic growth, sustainability and job creation.

The funds are expected to attract more businesses to the region, further stimulating the local economy. Hart expressed hopes that such a significant investment would send a clear message to businesses across the UK and beyond about Wales' readiness for economic development.

McCullum started off the day with some hope, but it was soon extinguished as wickets fell like dominos around him. The audience watched in dismay as their team failed to seize control of the game.

original: The company said it had been cleared by government officials in Senegal to launch an evaluation plan. Cairn, which made two discoveries in the area last year, estimated fields there could contain more than a billion barrels of oil. Its evaluation plan will start shortly with a 3D seismic survey. Later this year it aims to launch a multi-well exploration and appraisal programme. Edinburgh-based Cairn has a 40% interest in three blocks offshore Senegal (Sangomar Deep, Sangomar Offshore, Rufisque Offshore). Its partners include ConocoPhillips (35%) and FAR Ltd (15%), with Petrosen, the Senegal National Oil Company, retaining a 10% interest in the exploration phase. In its latest half-yearly report, Cairn also said that it had started international arbitration proceedings with the government of India over a tax row. Cairn has been prevented by Indian authorities from accessing the value of its 10% residual shareholding in Cairn India Limited (CIL). original: The country's Chamber of Deputies had already approved the legislation. The vote in the Senate, which backed the bill by just six votes, came after 14 hours of at times heated debate. The law, which also allows same-sex couples to adopt, had met with fierce opposition from the Catholic Church and other religious groups. The legislation, backed by President Cristina Fernandez's centre-left government, passed by 33 votes to 27 with three abstentions. Outside Congress, as the debate continued into the early hours of Thursday, supporters and opponents of the bill held rival demonstrations. original:
The removal of the engines, which have lain idle for two years, would leave 142 active vehicles in the capital. Savings from the proposal would amount to approximately $2 million annually, a considerable injection into the city's economy. The municipality's plan is to recycle these engines and parts for other uses, aiming to promote a more sustainable city model.

This decision follows the city's commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote an eco-friendly transportation system. The fleet's reduction has raised concerns among certain groups, which argue that it could lead to delays in public services. Despite this, the city council insists it's an essential move towards sustainability and efficient resource management.

The savings will be redirected to enhance public transportation services and infrastructure, which is expected to benefit around 700,000 daily commuters. The city council believes this plan will not only benefit the environment but also promote a healthier lifestyle among residents. The removal is set to commence next month.

She was speaking at an event on Thursday to remember four men who were shot dead by the SAS in her home village of Clonoe in County Tyrone over 30 years ago. The solemn gathering was held to commemorate Patrick Vincent, Peter Clancy, Sean O'Farrell, and Barry O'Donnell, who tragically lost their lives on February 16, 1992.

The solemn tribute was filled with poignant memories and heartfelt speeches, with emphasis on the importance of peace and reconciliation. The keynote speaker, a woman who had witnessed the tragic incident, urged the community to remember not just the lives lost, but also the need for unity and perseverance in the face of adversity.

This commemoration served as a stark reminder of the dark days of conflict in Northern Ireland, and the imperative for continued striving towards peace and understanding. Clonoe's residents, while honoring their past, look forward to a harmonious future, proving that their resilience remains an emblem of hope in the ongoing peace

original: The election commission (Inec) said it hoped to announce the winner on Monday. The UN has praised the poll despite technical hitches, protests and violence linked to Boko Haram. Voting spilled into a second day in some parts of Nigeria after problems with new electronic card readers. President Jonathan was among those unable to cast his vote using the technology, which was introduced to prevent fraud. His Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), who had opposed the card readers, called it a "huge national embarrassment". The Inec chair, Attahiru Jega, stressed that only a fraction of the 150,000 card readers being used nationwide had failed. The vote had been delayed by six weeks because of the insurgency by Boko Haram militants. Unpredictable poll Nigeria decides 2015: Full coverage The Islamists attacked polling stations in north-eastern states, with a curfew declared in Bauchi State after fighting between the security forces and the group. The UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon praised the "determination and resilience" of Nigerian voters,

In some Nigerian regions, voting extended into a second day due to problems with new electronic card readers. President Jonathan was among those who couldn't vote with the new system designed to curb fraud. His Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which opposed the card readers, labeled the situation a "huge national embarrassment." Inec chairman Attahiru Jega emphasized that only a small portion of the 150,000 card readers nationwide malfunctioned. The vote's schedule was delayed six weeks owing to Boko Haram's insurgency. The Islamist militants targeted polling stations in the northeast, prompting a curfew in Bauchi State after clashes with security forces. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon lauded the "determination and resilience" shown by Nigerian voters.

original: Masai Graham won with the gag: "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The festival's best jokes were selected by a panel of 10 judges before being put to 2,000 people, who voted for their favourite. Tim Vine, Stewart Francis and Zoe Lyon have previously won the competition, run by TV channel Dave. Graham, from West Bromwich, claimed the victory after making the shortlist in both 2014 and 2015. He said "It's an incredible honour to land Joke of the Fringe. Not bad for someone from West Brom!" Comedian Stuart Mitchell came second in the poll, with the joke: "Why is it old people say 'there's no place like home', yet when you put them in one..." Judges sat through an average of 60 different comedy performances and sifted through more than 3,600 minutes of material before selecting their favourite gags. In a bid to judge only the quality of the joke, the name of the comic or their show is not revealed during the voting process. Steve North, general manager of
variant_1: Masai Graham clinched the win with the gag: "My dad advised me to sign up for a donor card, he's truly a man after my own heart." A panel of 10 judges picked the festival's best jokes before 2,000 attendees voted for their favorite. Previous winners include Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, and Zoe Lyon. The competition is hosted by the TV channel Dave. Hailing from West Bromwich, Graham secured the top spot after being on the shortlist in 2014 and 2015. He remarked, "It's a tremendous honor to win Joke of the Fringe. Not bad for someone from West Brom!" Comedian Stuart Mitchell was the runner-up with the joke: "Why do elderly people say 'there's no place like home', yet when you put them in one..." Judges watched an average of 60 comedy acts and reviewed over 3,600 minutes of material to select the best jokes. To ensure fairness, the comedian's name and show were kept confidential during voting. Steve North serves as the general manager of the event.

original: Buckingham Palace announced on Friday evening that the Queen would not attend because she had gastroenteritis. Lord Lieutenant of West Glamorgan Byron Lewis took over the ceremonial role. The battalion's commanding officer said it would have been a first to have been presented leeks by the Queen. The cancellation by the Queen led to more sparse crowds watching the ceremony than had been anticipated. Speaking beforehand, commanding officer Rob Manuel said it had been "a bit of a surprise" when the announcement that the Queen would not be attending was made. However, he told BBC News: "We switched to plan B, and our thoughts and wishes are with her and we hope that she makes a speedy recovery. "The lord lieutenant has stepped into the breach. Today is going to run as per normal. "It would have certainly been a first for the queen to present leeks to 3rd Battalion, being a reserve battalion, especially for the chaps who have just come back from Afghanistan just before Christmas. "To have their leeks presented by the commander-in-chief is a really special day and really shows that the

original: The proposals are believed to include tougher English language requirements for students. Dominic Scott, head of the UK Council for International Student Affairs, said it would be a "nail in the coffin" for recruiting overseas students. The Home Office has argued there are no limits on numbers of genuine students. Universities have already been lobbying ministers to remove overseas students from migration targets - but the new English language proposals, if they were given the go-ahead, would mean even an higher threshold for entry. Universities argue that overseas students are increasingly important to the UK economy and that raising more barriers sends out a negative message in this competitive global market. Universities UK says overseas students are worth Â£7bn to the UK each year. Mr Scott, head of the advisory body on international students, described the revised language requirements as "pretty extreme". He warned that if implemented they would have a "massively damaging effect" on universities wanting to recruit overseas students, preventing about 15% of the current intake from gaining visas. Mr Scott said universities of all kinds saw the proposals as a "major concern" and would be

original: Mr Joshua told his congregation on Sunday that he "saw" a woman winning. After Donald Trump convincingly won Tuesday's vote, visitors to the preacher's Facebook page noticed the prophecy had been removed. The wealthy pastor is known as "the prophet" to his many followers. He is one of Nigeria's best-known and influential evangelists - and is popular across Africa, with many top politicians among his flock. The US election prediction was broadcast on Mr Joshua's TV channel Emmanuel TV, which an individual uploaded to YouTube. A section of that "prophecy" was posted on the preacher's Facebook page but is no longer available. "Ten days ago I saw the president of America with a narrow win... What I frankly saw was a woman," it said. TB Joshua has been trending on Twitter across Nigeria, Ghana and South Africa as people shared memes poking fun at his prediction. People have also taken to a Facebook entry he posted on Wednesday to complain. Clive Mashiri from South Africa asked: "Why was the prophecy deleted? The three-day event was launched by tourist body Welcome to Yorkshire after the county hosted the Tour de France Grand Depart in 2014. More than 1.2m people lined the 320-mile (515km) route. Mr Parnaby said last year's event had attracted thousands of spectators to the East Riding. "The council feels that the investment made by the authority, circa £100,000, to bring part of the race here is money well spent and will provide opportunities for local traders to capitalise on increased spending and help boost the East Riding economy," he said. original:
S4C gets most of its income from the licence fee and UK ministers have announced a major review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies has endorsed this initiative, suggesting the review will ensure a more transparent and accountable broadcasting service. 

The BBC currently operates under a Royal Charter, which is up for renewal every 10 years. This review will assess its public purposes, funding, and governance structure. Critics have raised concerns about the potential for political interference, however, Davies argued that the review will only enhance the BBC’s ability to deliver high-quality content to its viewers.

S4C, the Welsh-language public-service television channel, will also be impacted by this review. It heavily relies on the licence fee, receiving around 90% of its income from this source. The review will scrutinise the efficiency and effectiveness of this funding model, potentially impacting S4C's future operation. The results of the review will be awaited with interest by both viewers and broadcasters.

original: PC Frances Tilley admitted she had "destroyed her career" after evading payment for a journey between Bristol Temple Meads station and Castle Cary in Somerset last June. A disciplinary hearing at Northamptonshire Police headquarters heard she was less than two years into her job and was still on probation. She was dismissed for gross misconduct. The hearing at Wootton Hall heard Tilley travelled from Northampton to Castle Cary on 22 June last year. The officer, described as "diligent, professional and committed", was travelling with friends and did not buy a ticket for the final leg of her journey. Force solicitor Elizabeth Briggs said: "She travelled from Bristol to Westbury and onto Castle Cary. At that stage, she did not have a valid ticket to travel. "There were opportunities for her to purchase a ticket. "She said it was her intention to not pay a rail fare for that part of the journey." original: The charity wants 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by civil war to be resettled by the end of the year. Ahead of UN talks in Geneva on the crisis, it highlighted figures showing only 1.4% had been helped so far. Oxfam said UK plans to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020 were "not good enough", but Britain says it is also focused on providing aid to people in the region. The UK's pledge of Â£2.3bn to help people affected by the humanitarian crisis caused by the civil war in Syria makes it the second largest bilateral donor in the world after the US. Oxfam says while Britain has been generous in providing financial aid for those displaced by Syria's civil war, it "can and should do more". It argues that countries with strong economies and developed infrastructures need to shoulder a greater responsibility towards refugees than nations such as Lebanon and Jordan, where thousands of Syrians are now based. The Geneva conference should, the UK-based charity added, result in "urgent solutions, offering people safe and legal routes to a welcome" in other countries.

The UK, with a Â£2.3bn contribution, ranks as the second-largest bilateral donor after the US. Oxfam acknowledges Britain's financial generosity but insists it can and should increase efforts. The Geneva conference, the UK charity stated, must lead to immediate solutions and safe, legal pathways for refugees to find refuge in other countries.

It says the panel has no jurisdiction and its activities in the region will not be affected. The Asia-Europe Meeting Summit (Asem) in Ulaanbaatar in Mongolia on Friday and Saturday will be the first major multilateral diplomatic gathering since the 12 July ruling over the South China Sea. original:
The party's election manifesto said a funding floor would only be provided after a referendum was called. The St David's Day Agreement had said the vote should be held before such a move could be made. The seeming inconsistency has sparked a fierce debate among political parties and citizens alike, questioning the party's commitment to financial transparency and accountability.

Critics suggest that the move is a strategic ploy for the party to gain a political advantage, while supporters argue that it is a necessary step toward ensuring the smooth allocation of resources. The decision has also raised questions about the party's adherence to the St David's Day Agreement, which many view as a cornerstone of political practice and a pillar of democratic engagement. 

The party, in response to the concerns raised, maintains its stance that this move is in line with its commitment to strengthen democracy and promote fairer distribution of resources. Despite the controversy, the party stands firm on its decision, stating that the referendum is not an obstacle, but a necessary democratic process.
variant_1: The party's election manifesto indicates that the funding floor would be established only after a referendum takes place. The St David's Day Agreement, however, stipulated that the vote must occur before any such funding move. This apparent contradiction has ignited intense debate among politicians and the public, raising concerns about the party's dedication to financial transparency and responsibility.
variant_2: According to the party’s manifesto, funding would be set after holding a referendum, whereas the St David’s Day Agreement specifies that the vote should precede any funding action. Charles Mumbere, the king of Rwenzururu, is entitled to these privileges because he suffers from hypertension and diabetes, it added. The royal family has requested special medical care and dietary accommodations for the ailing king, citing his dual conditions that require meticulous attention. 

In response to this request, the government has confirmed that they will ensure the necessary measures are taken to guarantee the king's health. An official statement released yesterday stated, "The government is committed to providing the best possible care for King Mumbere. We recognize his significant role in our country's history and his current state of health demands special attention."

King Mumbere has been battling hypertension and diabetes for many years now. His condition has raised concerns among the kingdom's subjects, who regard him as a significant symbol of unity and cultural heritage. original: The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates. A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, who were elected as SNP MPs but now sit as independent members. Labour's executive is also expected to decide candidate selection, while some challengers have come forward for the Conservatives and Lib Dems already. The UK goes to the polls on 8 June after Prime Minister Theresa May announced plans for a snap election, subsequently endorsed by MPs by 552 votes to 13. Ms McGarry and Ms Thomson were the only two Scottish MPs to vote against the election, with SNP members abstaining. If they do not return, the SNP will need to find five candidates, including three for the seats the party did not win in 2015. A number of party activists have already announced their intention to bid for the SNP ticket in the Glasgow East and Edinburgh West seats formerly occupied by the two women. On Friday, the UK Labour party issued a call for prospective for parliamentary candidates over Twitter, inviting party members to apply with a deadline
variant_1: The 54 current MPs of the party are anticipated to be reselected as candidates. A decision is also pending about Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, who were originally SNP MPs but currently serve as independents. Labour's executive committee is expected to finalize candidate selections, with challengers already stepping forward for the Conservative and Liberal Democrat parties. The UK will hold elections on 8 June following Prime Minister Theresa May's announcement of a snap election, confirmed by MPs in a 552 to 13 vote. Ms McGarry and Ms Thomson were the only Scottish MPs voting against the election, while SNP members abstained. If they are not re-elected, SNP needs to find five new candidates, including three for constituencies lost in 2015. Several party activists have declared their candidacies for SNP nominations in the Glasgow East and Edinburgh West constituencies previously held by these two women. Recently, the UK Labour party invited prospective parliamentary candidates via Twitter, calling for applications by a set deadline.

original:
Ben Purdy, 18, was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex about "threatening" messages sent after their breakup. 

Ben Purdy, 18, was shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex about "threatening" messages sent after their break-up. The tragic incident, which took place around 11 PM on Sunday, has left the community in shock and mourning. 

Purdy, known for his bravery and sense of justice, had reportedly approached the man in an attempt to quell the tension that had been building since the break-up. Unfortunately, the confrontation escalated to a deadly turn, resulting in the fatal shooting of the young man. 

Local authorities are investigating the case rigorously, while the community rallies together in memory of Purdy. The alleged shooter, now identified as the ex-boyfriend, is in police custody awaiting trial. This tragic event highlights the escalating issue of gun violence and the urgent need for a solution. As the investigation unfolds, the community holds its breath, hoping for justice for Ben Purdy.

This week we got another example of that in the capital when oBike launched. It is a company backed by considerable venture capital and it's putting hundreds of hire bikes on London's streets. The company aims to have thousands in the capital by the end of the summer, after already operating huge schemes in South East Asia. variant_1: This suggests that instead of individuals owning cars or bikes, a possible future involves everyone hiring transportation when needed. Recently, the capital witnessed this concept's growth when oBike launched. Backed by significant venture capital, the company deployed hundreds of rental bikes across London. By summer's end, the company plans to have thousands available, building on large-scale operations in Southeast Asia. Unlike the current bike hire scheme, oBike's bikes don’t require docking stations. They feature a locking rear brake allowing users to leave them anywhere. Accessible via an app with GPS tracking, users pay a one-time £49 refundable deposit and 50p per 30 minutes. More companies are expected to follow, and oBike plans to complement the existing service.

Unlike traditional cycle hire schemes, these bikes don’t need docking stations—they have a locking rear brake so they can be left anywhere.
