The child, who was under 13, needed medical treatment following the attack by Ajay Jetha last year. A probation report three months earlier had identified Jetha as a potential risk to minors but lamentably, authorities failed to act. 

The attack, which occurred in Leicester, sparked public outrage and demands for a review of the probation system. It was revealed that Jetha, a 35-year-old man with a history of violent behavior, was not properly monitored after the damning report.

Prosecutors say the victim was subjected to a terrifying ordeal that has left her traumatized. The attack became a watershed moment, prompting serious questions about the effectiveness of the probation service in predicting and preventing such horrifying incidents. 

Jetha has since been sentenced to 10 years in prison. Meanwhile, the victim's family, with the support of their local community, is calling for a complete overhaul of the probation system to ensure no other child falls through the cracks.

LG was one of the first smartphone makers to reveal it would feature the assistant on its new device, the G6. Google's update will starting rolling out this week to users with Android 6.0 Marshmallow or 7.0 Nougat installed. "With this update, hundreds of millions of Android users will now be able to try out the Google Assistant," said Gummi Hafsteinsson, product lead for Google Assistant, in a blog post. original: It means instead of people owning cars and bikes, one version of the future is we all hire transport to get around. This week we got another glimpse into this potential future with Uber announcing its expansion into the e-bike rental industry. The ride-hailing giant has acquired Jump, a startup that provides dockless electric bikes allowing users to pick up and drop off bikes anywhere in the city. This move is a strategic pivot for Uber, a company traditionally associated with private car services, showcasing their willingness to adapt to the changing landscape of urban transportation. As we move towards a more sustainable and interconnected world, shared modes of transport, including bike sharing systems like Jump, are increasingly viewed as a viable alternative to private vehicle ownership. While there are still kinks to iron out, such as regulation and infrastructure, this acquisition indicates we're one step closer to a future where personal vehicle ownership may not be the norm.

original: OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. variant_1: OUP analyzed over 120,421 short stories penned by children aged five to 13 who participated in the BBC's 500 Words competition. OUP reports that technology is increasingly dominating children's lives, and their writing about it is evolving rapidly. Words like email, mobile, and Facebook are declining, replaced by terms such as Instagram, Snapchat, and emoji. The term television has been overtaken by phone in usage. The study also highlights a new trend: children frequently use the hashtag symbol # to add extra meaning or comments at the end of sentences, like #IblameTwitter or #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta from Oxford University Press noted that 2015 saw a significant shift in the way # is used, with children extending its role beyond just a prefix or search term.
variant_2: Oxford University Press evaluated more than 120,421 short stories submitted by children between five and 13 years old for the BBC's 500 Words contest. According to OUP, technology is taking an ever more central role in children's lives, and their writing about it is rapidly shifting. Usage of words like email, mobile, and Facebook is declining, replaced by Instagram, Snapchat, and emoji. The word television is now being replaced by phone. The report further notes the rising popularity of the hashtag # symbol used to add extra commentary or meaning at the sentence end, as seen with #IblameTwitter and #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta from OUP remarked that this change in hashtag usage has been notable in 2015, with children extending its function beyond a mere prefix or search term.

The report also observes a novel trend: the hashtag # is commonly used at sentence ends to add extra meaning, for example #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. original: The Black Caps, having been set a world record 504 to win, resumed on 142-3 and their challenge quickly folded. Brendon McCullum hit a run-a-ball 80 but the Kiwis were all out for 295. Spinner Nathan Lyon took 3-63 in the second innings, while Mitchell Starc, Josh Hazlewood and Mitchell Marsh claimed two wickets apiece. Australia's first innings 556-4 declared set them up for the victory and opener David Warner was named man of the match for his scores of 163 and 116. "I thought the first morning really set the tone for us with Joe Burns and Davy Warner batting so well," Australia captain Steve Smith said. "I thought the top order set the test match up for us. The partnerships that we had in that top three were crucial to our success." The second Test begins in Perth on Friday and the series concludes with the inaugural day-night Test in Adelaide. New Zealand now face a tough task

Nathan Lyon, the spinner, took 3-63 in the second innings, while Mitchell Starc, Josh Hazlewood, and Mitchell Marsh each picked up two wickets. Australia's commanding first innings total of 556-4 declared paved the way for their win, with opener David Warner named man of the match for his double centuries scores of 163 and 116. Australia captain Steve Smith commented, "The first morning really set the mood with Joe Burns and Davy Warner's strong batting. The top order's foundations were vital for our victory. The partnerships among our top three were key." The next Test starts in Perth on Friday and the series wraps up with the inaugural day-night Test in Adelaide. New Zealand faces a difficult challenge now.

original:
Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been named as new Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned after more than four years in charge. "We feel that Joe Root is the perfect choice to take over the reins from Alastair Cook," said the England Cricket Board (ECB) in a statement. Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been named as the new Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned after more than four years in charge. Cook's resignation marked the end of an era and the beginning of Root's leadership. 

Root, 30, is considered one of the best batsmen in the world, with a Test average of close to 50. His appointment reflects his consistent performance and the respect he commands within the squad. "We are confident that he will lead the team to new heights," the ECB statement added. Root will be the 80th man to lead England in a Test match when he takes charge for the first time this summer. His first series in charge will be against South Africa at home. Root's vice-captain will be Ben Stokes.

The walk-in service is aimed at reducing doctor appointments and to help reduce the over-use of antibiotics, NHS England said. It is hoped that the new approach will provide a more efficient and effective means for patients seeking treatment for minor ailments, potentially cutting down waiting times and easing the pressure on general practices.

The service is a strategic step in implementing the overarching goal of NHS England to manage antibiotic resistance, a growing health concern worldwide. Overuse of antibiotics has been linked to the emergence of resistant bacterial strains, posing a significant global health risk.

The walk-in service will be based in pharmacies across England, with trained practitioners providing on-the-spot advice and treatment without the requirement of an appointment. The list of ailments to be covered under the service includes sore throats, colds, and minor infections.

NHS England believes that this initiative will not only reduce the strain on GP surgeries and hospitals but also help in educating the public about the perils of overusing antibiotics. By integrating pharmacies more deeply into the healthcare

original:
The Spy Who Came In From The Cold, set at the height of the Cold War, is being adapted by the Oscar-winning writer of The Imitation Game, Graham Moore. The espionage thriller, originally a novel by John le Carré, will be making its transition into a gripping television drama. Moore, known for his ability to masterfully craft complex narratives, is set to bring a fresh perspective to the classic Cold War story.

The novel's protagonist, Alec Leamas, a hardworking British agent who is in the throes of the East-West conflict in Berlin, will be the focal point of this adaptation. The story's timeless themes of loyalty, betrayal, and human integrity are set to be explored in depth, promising a thrilling experience for viewers.

This adaptation is expected to bring a new generation of viewers closer to le Carré’s work, while also pleasing long-time fans with its faithful rendition of the novel’s atmospheric tension and intricate plot. The production date is yet to be announced,

The Royal couple will attend a series of engagements in Londonderry, Belfast and County Down during their visit. During their visit to Bellaghy, the Royal couple toured the visitors' centre. The village inspired many of Seamus Heaney's most memorable lines. Prince Charles has had a long interest in the Nobel prize-winning poet's work and met him on a number of occasions. After leaving Bellaghy, they met staff and patients at the North West Cancer Centre at Altnagelvin Hospital in Londonderry. On Tuesday evening they attended a musical gathering at Hillsborough Castle, in County Down. They are also expected to officially open a memorial garden to members of the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) who were killed while on duty. original: The Crawick Multiverse, designed by renowned artist Charles Jencks, has been created with materials found on the site in Dumfries and Galloway. The Â£1m project on land near Sanquhar was funded by the Duke of Buccleuch. It will be launched on Sunday with a performance by a cast of 30 dancers and musicians. The Crawick Artland Trust, which manages the site, has said it hopes to attract international visitors and boost business in Sanquhar, Kelloholm and Kirkconnel. The opening performance, which coincides with the Summer solstice, is called Oceanallover and it has been specially developed by artistic director Alex Rigg. He said: "Through conversations with Charles Jencks and with the Duke of Buccleuch and the local community, it is clear to me that my job is to present something which is interesting to look at in itself but allows other people to see the potential of the site for future events." The performance is likely to raise questions, rather than answer them, he said. "It's likely to be quite abstract at times
variant_1: The Crawick Multiverse, crafted by the celebrated artist Charles Jencks, was built using materials sourced locally in Dumfries and Galloway. This £1 million project on land close to Sanquhar received funding from the Duke of Buccleuch. It is set to launch on Sunday, featuring a performance with 30 dancers and musicians. The Crawick Artland Trust, which oversees the site, hopes to draw international tourists and invigorate business in Sanquhar, Kelloholm, and Kirkconnel. The inaugural performance, aligned with the Summer solstice, is named Oceanallover and was uniquely created by artistic director Alex Rigg. "Discussions with Charles Jencks, the Duke of Buccleuch, and local residents have clarified that my role is to present something visually engaging that also helps others envision the site's potential for future occasions," he explained. The show aims to provoke questions instead of providing answers, he added, noting that it might be somewhat abstract at times.

original: The changes would allow Japanese troops to fight abroad for the first time since World War Two. The legislation has already been passed by Japan's lower house, signalling a significant shift from Japan's post-war pacifism and marking a milestone in its military normalization. The bill, if approved by the upper house, would extend Japan's military options by ending a ban on exercising collective self-defense, or aiding an ally under attack. While supporters argue that it is crucial for Japan to strengthen its role in global security amid growing regional threats, the move has triggered widespread protests from citizens and constitutional scholars who contend it violates Japan's constitution and could potentially embroil the country in U.S.-led conflicts around the globe. This legislation is a reflection of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's push for Japan to take on a more assertive military posture, a stance that has raised eyebrows within the international community.

Proponents believe strengthening Japan's role in global security is vital amid rising regional threats. However, the legislation has sparked widespread protests from citizens and constitutional experts who argue it breaches Japan's constitution and risks entanglement in U.S.-led military actions worldwide. The bill reflects Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's effort to make Japan's military more assertive, a policy that has drawn concern internationally.

The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association said it condemned abusive behaviour. The singer wrote on Twitter: "Just tried to get in a black cab with my kids. The driver looked at me and said 'find an immigrant to drive you you stupid tart'." Taibu, 32, played 28 Test matches and 150 one-day internationals for Zimbabwe prior to retiring in 2012. "When he explained who he was, it was like meeting a legend in person," said young fan, Tinashe Moyo, who had never had the chance to see the wicketkeeper-batsman play in his prime. 

In his ten-year career, Taibu was renowned for his technical proficiency, agility behind the stumps, and captaincy. His retirement shocked many, as he was still at the peak of his prowess, but he cited personal and family reasons for his decision.

Since hanging up his cricket pads, Taibu has devoted his time to promoting and developing the sport at grassroots level in African communities. Many young athletes have benefited from his mentorship and training, and his dedication to giving back to the sport has been lauded by sporting and community figures alike.

Taibu's career might have ended on the pitch, but his

The were 37 crimes recorded in Cromer over the weekend - including the rape of a teenager - with residents linking them to a group of travellers. The weekend saw an alarming total of 37 crimes recorded in Cromer, including a horrifying incident of a teenage girl being raped. Local residents believe the crimes are linked to a group of travellers who moved into the area recently.

The spate of incidents began on Friday night, with reports of thefts, disturbances, and disorderly behaviour. But it was the sexual assault on the teenager that has left the community in shock and fear. Local authorities are treating the incident with utmost severity and have launched a full-scale investigation.

The police are conducting regular patrols and checks in the area to ensure residents' safety. Authorities have also called for calm and urged residents not to take matters into their own hands, assuring them that every possible step is being taken to bring the culprits to justice.

Residents have been asked to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activities to the police. The incidents have sparked a debate about the need for better security measures in the seaside town.

But he fancied his video game skills and entered Nissan's GT Academy competition while on a gap year. After beating 90,000 other gamers from across the globe, the prodigious talent, Joe Smith, stepped into the spotlight. 

Many scoffed at the idea of a video gamer transitioning into a professional race car driver, but Smith proved them wrong. The 23-year-old demonstrated his skill set was not confined to virtual competitions. His tenacity, determination, and an uncanny knack for strategic gameplay led him to outpace his competitors and clinch the championship. 

Smith's incredible journey from a casual gamer to a professional racer has not only redefined traditional pathways into motorsports but also validated the place of e-sports in mainstream competition. His victory at the GT Academy has set a precedent, proving that passion, dedication, and skill can overcome traditional barriers. This triumph signifies a victory for all e-sports enthusiasts and a game-changing moment for the world of competitive racing.

original: These beautiful pictures are the first ever taken of a wild lioness nursing a cub from a different species - an extremely rare event. The pair were spotted by Joop Van Der Linde, a guest at Ndutu Safari Lodge in Tanzania's Ngorongoro Conservation Area. The scene is the Serengeti; the attentive mother, five-year-old Nosikitok. The lioness has a GPS collar fitted by Kope Lion, a conservation NGO, and three young cubs of her own - born around the 27-28 June. Dr Luke Hunter, President and Chief Conservation Officer for Panthera, a global wild cat conservation organisation which supports Kope Lion, told the BBC the incident was "truly unique". "It's not something that I'm aware has ever happened before between large cats like this," he said. "We know there are cases where lionesses will adopt other lion cubs... But this is unprecedented. "I know of no other case - between any large cat, for that matter - where the
variant_1: These stunning photos capture the first-ever observation of a wild lioness nursing a cub from a different species, an extraordinarily rare occurrence. The duo was seen by Joop Van Der Linde, a visitor at Ndutu Safari Lodge within Tanzania's Ngorongoro Conservation Area. The setting is the Serengeti and the caring mother is a five-year-old lioness named Nosikitok. She wears a GPS collar from Kope Lion, a conservation NGO, and has three cubs born around June 27-28. Dr. Luke Hunter, President and Chief Conservation Officer of Panthera, a global wild cat conservation organization supporting Kope Lion, described the event to the BBC as "truly unique." He noted, "I am not aware of this happening previously between large cats. We know lionesses sometimes adopt other lion cubs, but this case is unprecedented. I am unaware of any other large cat event like this."

Dr. Luke Hunter, President and Chief Conservation Officer at Panthera (a global wild cat conservation body backing Kope Lion), told the BBC the scene was "truly unique." He expressed that he was not aware such occurrences had happened between large cats before, explaining lionesses sometimes raise other lion cubs but this is unmatched in precedent. original:
The latest Markit Report on Jobs for Scotland found sharp rises in permanent and temporary job placements in April. Growth in temporary staff demand was also at its highest rate since December 2018, providing positive signals about the Scottish job market. 

The report indicates an accelerated increase in permanent staff appointments, and recruiters signaled a strong upturn in short-term roles. This surge is particularly notable after the economic slowdown caused by the pandemic. The demand for workers is increasing in various sectors, with IT & Computing leading the way in permanent staff demand, whereas Nursing/Medical/Care topped the demand for temporary staff.

Moreover, the availability of candidates for permanent roles deteriorated at a steep and accelerated rate, leading to a surge in starting salaries. Meanwhile, temp wages also grew at a faster pace. 

This data suggests that Scotland's job market is bouncing back robustly, with increasing demand for both permanent and temporary staff and growing wages, bringing a much-needed boost to the Scottish economy.

original: An official has told an assembly committee that Cardiff Aviation, which has leased a hangar at St Athan from the administration since 2012, has not paid rent for the last three years. The Vale of Glamorgan-based maintenance and repair firm, co-owned by Iron Maiden singer Bruce Dickinson, faces financial difficulties since 2019, leading to delayed rent payments. The official disclosed that the outstanding rent totals an estimated £500,000. The revelation has sparked a significant concern among the assembly members over the administration's measures to ensure the collection of due payments. The company's failure to pay rent has put additional financial pressure on St Athan, already struggling due to the economic impact of the pandemic. Assembly members are now urging the administration to take immediate action to recoup the lost funds. Cardiff Aviation is yet to comment on the matter. This situation has highlighted the need for stricter enforcement of lease agreements to protect public finances.

original: Transport for London (TfL) is to consult on plans to demand a new English language test, a map-reading assessment, a fixed landline and the chance to book seven days in advance. Uber said: "If adopted these [rules] would mean an end to the Uber people know and love." Black cab drivers have argued regulations need to be tightened. There has been growing pressure on city legislators, most recently when cab drivers protested outside City Hall. The Uber app connects customers and nearby drivers using GPS technology and gives an estimate of the fare. It generally charges lower fares than traditional firms and drivers rely on technology for navigation. Transactions are cashless using pre-registered bank details. TfL says the consultation seeks to "raise standards across the industry" following an "exponential" growth in the private hire industry and technology. Uber said it was a deliberate target and if the proposals went ahead they would raise prices and increase congestion in London. Gareth Mead, from Uber, said: "If you think that this is supposed to be a public consultation, well I think the public are not at the

original: Yorkshire batsman Joe Root has been named as new Test captain after Alastair Cook resigned after more than four years in charge. "We need to win but we want to perform in a manner that makes people want to come and watch us," Stokes said. Root's first Test match as England skipper is against South Africa at Lord's beginning on 7 July. The 26-year-old has stepped up from vice-captain, with Durham all-rounder Stokes, 25, filling the role as his deputy. "Test cricket is the pinnacle and we need people to fall in love with it again," added Stokes. Discussing his elevation to vice-captain, he added: "Everything I do is to win and being vice-captain won't change me as a person or as a player. original:
Until now, Google Assistant had only been available on the firm's own Pixel phones. The service, akin to Siri on iPhones, allows users to interact with their devices using voice commands, delivering a hands-free, convenient experience. However, in a bid to make this feature more accessible, Google announced recently that it will be expanding the availability of Google Assistant to a wider range of smartphones.

This strategic move aims to compete directly with Apple's Siri and Amazon's Alexa, offering users of other Android devices the same high-quality, intelligent voice-controlled virtual assistant. This expansion will enable more users to enjoy the benefits of Google Assistant, such as setting reminders, sending texts, or asking for directions, all by just using their voice. 

This initiative places Google at the forefront of the drive to make technology more intuitive and user-friendly. By democratizing this cutting-edge technology, Google is not only reinforcing its commitment to innovation but also to inclusivity, ensuring all Android users can enjoy the benefits of a virtual assistant.

original: The H3 project combines back office services at four police, fire and council authorities in Hampshire and Oxfordshire, to save up to £5m a year. The Police Federation said payroll mistakes were among a "catalogue of errors" since H3 began in 2014. Hampshire's Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) said the investment would deliver improvements by May. A report to PCC Michael Lane said H3 had caused problems with recruitment and the management of staff sickness, as well as "weighing down" police officers with "back office processes which restrict their effectiveness". In February 2016, 1,300 officers received the wrong pay, while some allowances were wrongly calculated in March. In 2015, the BBC learned that payment delays to Hampshire County Council's suppliers had trebled. under the new system. Hampshire Police Federation chairman John Apter said the system had been "poorly conceived, implemented and delivered". original:
Ben Butler met a psychologist in 2004 after assaulting a man in a nightclub. Dr Tim Green wrote in his report that Mr Butler found it "difficult to control his anger", which was alarmingly indicative of his pattern of violent behavior. This observation has now resurfaced after Butler was convicted of further violent crimes, highlighting a disappointing failure of the legal and therapeutic systems in managing and averting such cases.

Butler's psychological assessment, made public after recent legal proceedings, underscored the warning signs that were seemingly overlooked. His inability to manage his angry reactions, which led to acts of violence, was not adequately addressed nor were preventive measures put in place.

The case of Ben Butler exposes a larger problem in the system where insufficient attention is given to repeated offenders exhibiting signs of systemic violence. It challenges the efficacy of our rehabilitative measures and prompts a call for more proactive action in managing violent individuals. The system's ability to protect citizens from repeat offenders remains under scrutiny.

original:
Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) said the force had "fragile" staffing levels and needed to "implement more robust human resource strategies."

Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary (HMIC) has issued a stark warning about frailty in police staffing levels, stating that the force currently operates with "fragile" staffing levels and needs to "implement more robust human resource strategies." This recent assessment has thrown light on the intensifying pressure faced by law enforcement agencies around the country, which are grappling with budget cuts and rising crime rates.

The Inspectorate called for immediate action to address the issue, suggesting that workforce planning and recruitment efforts are not keeping pace with the departure or retirement of experienced staff. HMIC emphasized that higher quality leadership and management, coupled with the implementation of a more strategic workforce plan, can help to stave off the staffing crisis.

Public safety is potentially at risk if these concerns are not addressed promptly. The HMIC's findings serve as an urgent call to action for the police forces to bolster their ranks and ensure the public's trust in their ability to maintain law and order.

original:
Gene Palmer is the second prison worker detained over the jail break. Joyce Mitchell has already been charged with aiding the escape. The prisoners, Richard Matt and David Sweat, were both serving lengthy sentences at the Clinton Correctional Facility.

Gene Palmer is the second prison worker detained over the jail break. Joyce Mitchell has already been charged with aiding the escape, having allegedly provided the prisoners with tools hidden inside meat. Palmer is believed to have unknowingly assisted in the escape, also under Mitchell's manipulation.

The prisoners, Richard Matt and David Sweat, have led authorities on a wild goose chase since their daring getaway. Both were serving sentences for murder. Their escape has triggered a massive manhunt, causing widespread fear and alarm across the region.

Palmer's arrest marks a new turn in an already complex investigation. His lawyer stated he will plead not guilty to the alleged charges, including promoting prison contraband and tampering with evidence.

As the drama continues to unfold, questions loom regarding the security and supervision of prisons. The incident has ignited a nationwide debate on the need for reform in the prison system and the responsibility of prison staff in ensuring the public's

original: Palmer expects to be fined by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) for the rule breach during Champions Day. "It was an oversight," Palmer told BBC Sport. "The wrong kit box was left in the lorry and taken to the stables." The Newmarket-based trainer saw Galilieo Gold finish fifth in the Group One Queen Elizabeth II Stakes at Ascot. Horses are only allowed to receive hay-feed or water before a race, but other substances such as electrolytes are permitted post-race. Employees of Palmer and fellow trainers, Francois Rohaut and and Jean-Claude Rouget, as well as the trainers themselves, were interviewed by stewards following a report by the Equine Welfare and Integrity Officer. Palmer is yet to hear what punishment the BHA will hand down. "I imagine there will be a routine fine for a rule that's been broken," he told BBC Radio Berkshire. "There's no suggestion that anyone was trying to seek an advantage or cheat. It's simply what the rule says. The rules are the rules and you need to stick to them."

"The incorrect kit box was left in the lorry and taken to the stables." Palmer, based in Newmarket, had Galileo Gold finish fifth in the Group One Queen Elizabeth II Stakes at Ascot. Only hay-feed or water are allowed to be given to horses before a race, though substances like electrolytes are permitted afterward. Palmer's staff, along with fellow trainers Francois Rohaut and Jean-Claude Rouget and the trainers themselves, were questioned by stewards following a report by the Equine Welfare and Integrity Officer. Palmer is still waiting to learn the BHA's decision on the penalty. "I expect a standard fine for the rule breach," he told BBC Radio Berkshire. "There's no indication anyone tried to gain an advantage or cheat. It's just a matter of following the rules. The rules exist to be followed."

original: The child, who was under 13, needed medical treatment following the attack by Ajay Jetha last year. A probation report three months earlier warned he might snatch a child "at any time", Leicester Crown Court heard. Jetha, 32, was told he must serve at least 11 years. Updates on this story and more from Leicestershire He previously admitted some offences relating to last year's attack but on Monday changed his plea to guilty to all 10 charges relating to the boy, known only as Child A, which included photographing his assault. He also admitted a further 10 unconnected child sex offences. During the sentencing hearing on Tuesday, it was revealed just three months before the brutal assault in Leicester a Probation Service report said "he could at any time take a child off the street". Speaking after the hearing, Lawrence English, from the Crown Prosecution Service, said: "The police were obviously aware of that [report]

original: Aiden Webb, 22, from Norwich, set off to climb the Fansipan mountain alone on 3 June. He called his girlfriend to say he had fallen, injuring himself. It is understood he later fell down the waterfall while trying to make it to safety. His body was found on 9 June. Tests showed he died at about 07:00 on 4 June, after falling 18m (60ft). More news from Norfolk Mr Webb, an experienced climber, had started his ascent of the 3,100m (10,300ft) high mountain at about 06:00 and planned to climb it in a day. He had gone to Vietnam with his girlfriend Bluebell Baughan, 24, of White Notley, Essex, and she was in contact with him by phone from the nearest town of Sapa. original:
Mr Carney said long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would promote financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he urged Germany to lead the global efforts in climate finance. 

Mr Carney said long-term financing of green projects in emerging markets would promote financial stability. Speaking at an event in Berlin, he urged Germany to leverage its economic strength and technological prowess to drive investment in sustainable initiatives worldwide. 

"Germany is in a unique position to steer global markets towards a greener future. This could bring not only environmental benefits but also economic gains, both for Germany and for the emerging countries," Mr Carney said. 

Highlighting the potential of green technology to create jobs and drive economic growth, Carney encouraged German businesses and financial institutions to invest in renewable energy and sustainable infrastructure projects in developing countries. He noted the importance of these investments in achieving the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

Carney's message underscores the central role of finance in tackling climate change and promoting sustainable development. It is a call for Germany, Europe's largest economy, to step up and lead the way in the global green finance movement.

African Union (AU) leaders are due to discuss the crisis in Burundi at a summit in Ethiopia. They want Mr Nkurunziza to accept peacekeeping troops to prevent Burundi sliding into ethnic conflict, but analysts say he is unlikely to agree. The controversial bid to change the historic club's name to something more modern was met with significant pushback from the loyal fanbase. The owner argued that a name change would attract new fans and bring in additional revenue, but traditionalists were adamant that the club's identity was not for sale.

Erika Murray, 31, was arrested on Thursday night after a neighbour alerted police over the safety of other children living at the house. Detectives swiftly responded to the call, arriving at the residence to initiate investigation. 

Upon arriving, officers found conditions to be severely neglectful and hazardous. The children present, all under the age of 10, were immediately taken into protective custody due to the apparent immediate threats to their wellbeing. 

While details surrounding the case remain to be fully disclosed, preliminary reports indicate that the children lived amidst squalor, with insufficient food and sanitation. Authorities express their deep concern over the long-term physical and psychological health of the affected children. 

Charged with multiple counts of child endangerment, Murray is set to face a judge early next week. As the investigation continues, authorities are working diligently to ensure the safety and welfare of the children involved. More updates will be provided as this heartbreaking story unfolds.

original: The holders, who also won the trophy in 2013, bowed out in the group stage despite six wins in 14 games. Promotion in the County Championship, though, is still a possibility. "We wanted to be in a position going into the last five games where we had something to play for, and we have," Ripley told BBC Radio Northampton. "We'll be pushing hard to get ourselves in there with maybe two games to go, one game to go. "I'm just looking forward to seeing us get stuck in and who knows, it could still be a pretty special season." With two promotion places available again this summer, Northants are currently third, 15 points behind second-placed Worcestershire, but with a game in hand. However, two of their remaining five matches are against leaders Nottinghamshire, the first starting at Trent Bridge on 28 August. "I'm looking forward to the first game because that will be like a Test match kind of atmosphere and a good challenge, but I'd probably take one of the other teams (rather than playing Notts twice)," said Ripley. "We've just got to play our best cricket for four days and if we get into a position

Retired West Indies international Chanderpaul put on 55 with Ryan McLaren, calming the innings after the early wickets, before the 42-year-old was joined by Clark when Gareth Batty dismissed McLaren. The pair then shared an unbeaten partnership of 172 with Clark - batting at eight in the order - soon overtaking Chanderpaul's score, beating him to his half-century. original: Tear gas and live bullets were fired to drive back the mainly Shia Muslim crowds, as they protested against corruption and security failures. Officials imposed a curfew in the Iraqi capital, which has now been lifted. It was the second time this month that protesters had managed to break into the city's government area. Shia Muslim cleric Moqtada Sadr condemned the use of force, and voiced support for the demonstrators' "peaceful [and] spontaneous revolt". At least 50 demonstrators are said to have been wounded. The protesters accuse the government of neglecting much-needed reforms, as it struggles with its campaign against the so-called Islamic State group (IS) and declining oil revenues. The Sunni jihadist group controls parts of western and northern Iraq and has been behind a wave of recent attacks that have left dozens killed. Some demonstrators managed to break into the prime minister's office and parliament. Baghdad's Green Zone houses the parliament, key government buildings and many foreign embassies. The authorities later said they had completely regained control of the area and the protesters had withdrawn. The Shia cleric and his militia group, the Mehdi Army, gained prominence after the US-led invasion

The demonstrators complain the government is ignoring urgent reforms while battling Islamic State militants and falling oil income. The Sunni militant group controls areas of western and northern Iraq and is responsible for recent deadly attacks. original:
The Financial Conduct Authority said these customers were profitable for card providers and so there were few incentives for the firms to intervene. It said customers should be wary and take necessary precautions to safeguard their financial interests. This follows from a recent study on the business practices of card providers, which revealed that their intervention in the financial decisions of profitable customers is minimal, often leading to unchecked spending. 

The FCA urged consumers to be more pro-active about their financial decisions, and not to rely solely on card companies for advice or intervention. It also recommended that customers regularly review their credit card usage and take advantage of financial tools and resources to manage their spending effectively. 

The FCA's statement highlights the need for consumer vigilance in a financial landscape that is often stacked in favor of card providers. The call for consumers to take charge of their financial decisions underscores the importance of financial literacy in today's society.

original: The interactive display can replicate the phone's touch screen, a full-size computer keyboard or even piano keys. The laser projector can also be used to beam images and videos onto walls. The Smart Cast phone was unveiled at the company's Tech World conference in Beijing, where the firm also unveiled a new type of smartwatch. The laser projector measures just 34mm by 26mm by 5mm and, said Lenovo, does not need focussing to project sharp images onto walls or other flat surfaces. A video showing the Smart Cast in action shows how twisting the mounting for the device's lens turns it from a standard wall projector into "surface mode" that beams the display on to a table top. A kickstand mounted on the back of the phone keeps the device upright while the virtual keyboard is in use. At Tech World, Chinese concert pianist Lang Lang used the virtual keyboard to play a version of The Entertainer. Mike Lowe, reviews editor at gadget site Pocket-lint, who has tried out

Entrants to the annual event have five minutes to tell the biggest and most convincing lie they can. Winner George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, has been crowned King of Fibs at the annual World's Biggest Liar competition, this year held virtually due to the ongoing pandemic.

Entrants to the annual event have five minutes to tell the biggest and most convincing lie they can. Winner George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, spun a remarkable tale about a band of alien frogs that had taken over his town, causing pandemonium as they croaked the national anthem out of tune at all hours. The judging panel was captivated by Kemp's wildly imaginative, yet utterly believable, deception and unanimously deemed him the winner. 

This unique contest, held in the Lake District, celebrates the traditional art of storytelling and the good, old-fashioned tall tale. Kemp's comically outrageous lie was a testament to his vivid imagination and knack for storytelling, which earned him the coveted title. The competition, a fun-filled exercise in creativity and wit, drew a plethora of participants from around the world, each showcasing their talent for falsehood

original:
North, 24, landed on his head after a high tackle from Adam Thompstone in his side's 19-11 defeat against Leicester Tigers on Saturday. The incident sparked major concern for the player's health as North remained motionless on the pitch for several minutes before being stretchered off.

Medical staff were quick to tend to the rugby star, with early reports suggesting that he may have suffered a concussion. The incident has reignited debates about player safety in rugby, with some calling for stricter enforcement of high-tackle rules.

The Rugby Football Union, the sport's governing body, has announced that it will conduct an immediate review into the incident. 

North's team, Northampton Saints, issued a statement expressing their concern for the player's well-being and promising to support him throughout his recovery. North has a history of concussions, which adds to the collective worry surrounding his recent injury.

This incident underscores the inherent risks of contact sports and calls for a renewed focus on player safety.

OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to their findings, the creativity and linguistic skill displayed by these budding authors were nothing short of remarkable. 

The stories covered a range of themes, reflecting the concerns, dreams, and fascinations of children across the UK. Climate change, pollution, and animal extinction emerged as prevalent issues, indicating the young participants’ acute awareness of environmental challenges. The narratives also explored themes of adventure, friendship, and family, demonstrating children's understanding of complex emotional dynamics.

The analysis revealed a striking use of vocabulary, with words like 'pandemic,' 'lockdown,' and 'virus' prominent, reflecting the influence of the Covid-19 crisis on children's lives. Additionally, an increase in the use of technology-related words was observed. 

This research underscores the power of storytelling as a medium for children to express their perceptions and understanding of the

Seamer Abbott, 29, and top-order batsman Rossouw, 27, confirmed their international retirements in January. The young duo's decision to withdraw from the international cricket circuit came as a surprise to many fans and critics alike. Abbott, known for his steely consistency, and Rossouw, renowned for his tenacity at the crease, have been significant contributors to their national teams. 

The decision to retire early is understood to be a personal choice for both players, motivated by a desire to focus on their domestic careers. Their retirement has sparked a fresh debate on the increasing demands of international cricket on players' physical and mental health.

However, their departure from the international scene does not mean a complete disappearance from the cricket field. Both players plan to continue playing at the domestic level, bringing their skills and experience to benefit their local teams. As cricket enthusiasts bid farewell to the international careers of these talented players, they look forward to witnessing their continued contributions to the sport.

original: The A320 pilot reported seeing a white quadcopter drone "flash past" the aircraft while travelling south of Brookmans Park last August. No avoiding action was possible due to the lack of available time, a UK Airprox Board report said. It concluded a "collision had only been narrowly avoided and chance had played a major part". Air traffic control said the A320 pilot reported that "something had just gone over the top of him" at about 18:45 BST on 15 August 2016 while flying north of Potters Bar. The controller said another aircraft had just crossed above but the pilot said the object was red and white in colour, had red and blue stripes on two of the rotor arms and was under a metre in size. All drone operators are required to observe Air Navigation Order (ANO) 2016 articles which require a person in charge of a small unmanned aircraft to only fly the aircraft if reasonably satisfied the flight can safely be made ,and not to recklessly or negligently cause or permit an aircraft to endanger any person or

original: Gene Palmer is the second prison worker detained over the jail break. Joyce Mitchell has already been charged with aiding the escape. The prisoners, Richard Matt and David Sweat, used power tools to flee the Clinton Correctional Facility. A massive manhunt is still under way to find the pair, both convicted killers. Mr Palmer has been held on bail, after appearing before a judge on charges of promoting prison contraband, tampering with physical evidence, and official misconduct. His lawyer, Andrew Brockway, admitted his client delivered the meat but said he did not know it contained the tools, nor that the prisoners were trying to escape. "He did pass the hamburger meat. He shouldn't have done it. He apologised for it,'' said Mr Brockway, who added his client plans to plead not guilty. Clinton County District Attorney Andrew Wylie said Ms Mitchell placed hacksaw blades and other tools inside the meat, before Mr Palmer took it to Matt and Sweat, who were interred in a section of the jail where prisoners can cook their own meals. Meanwhile, officers are concentrating their search on a 75 sq mi (194 sq km) area of northern New

The number given for the current account customers hit by the fraud is fewer than half of the 20,000 initially reported to have been affected. Personal information and account numbers were exposed in a sophisticated scam, causing widespread panic among account holders. 

The breach, orchestrated by a group of cybercriminals, initially appeared to have impacted one in every hundred customers of the major bank. However, following rigorous investigations by the cybercrime department, the actual figure was revised down to less than 10,000. 

The bank assured that they have taken immediate action to safeguard those affected, including resetting passwords and monitoring accounts for suspicious activity. They also urged customers to remain vigilant, stressing the importance of not sharing sensitive information via email or over the phone.

In a statement, the bank said, "We deeply regret the concern and inconvenience this incident may have caused. We are committed to protecting our customers' data and have taken steps to prevent such incidents in the future."

Officers at first did not treat Stephen Phillips's death as suspicious after he was found in his Wolverhampton flat. His family became suspicious when they discovered unusual transactions in his bank account, leading to a deeper investigation into his sudden demise.

The Phillips family noted several withdrawals that appeared to be out of character for Stephen, who was known as a meticulous and careful individual, especially concerning his finances. This alarming discovery prompted them to request authorities for a more thorough investigation into his death.

Upon their request, the West Midlands Police launched a more substantial inquiry, utilising the full extent of their forensic capabilities. The startling results revealed the presence of a rare toxin in his system, suggesting foul play. This shocking turn of events has devastated the family and friends of Stephen Phillips.

The police have since arrested a suspect linked to the unusual transactions in Stephen's bank account. However, the investigation is ongoing. This tragic revelation serves as a reminder of the importance of vigilance in our everyday lives, even in seemingly ordinary circumstances

Geoffrey Stewart, 74, of Dumfries, was one of three men in their 60s and 70s who went missing in the Scottish highlands yesterday. Geoffrey Stewart, 74, of Dumfries, was one of three men in their 60s and 70s who went missing in the treacherous terrain of the Highlands, sparking a large-scale search and rescue operation.

The trio, all experienced hikers, were last seen embarking on a walking trail near Ben Nevis, Britain’s highest peak, early Tuesday morning. Alarm bells rang after they failed to return to their lodging by late evening, which was unusual given their hiking routine.

Mountain rescue teams from Fort William, Lochaber, and Skye, as well as a coastguard helicopter, were deployed for the search operation. Despite challenging weather conditions, including heavy rain, strong winds, and low visibility, the search teams have remained optimistic.

original: Christopher Kelly, 40, strangled his friend Dorothy Beattie, 51, at her home in Dunoon, Argyll and Bute, on 22 May. The High Court in Glasgow heard he attacked her after she allegedly made a jibe about his children. Kelly, who was caught after confessing to a GP, was originally charged with murder but pleaded guilty to the lesser charge of culpable homicide. The court heard how Kelly had previously been a support worker for Ms Beattie, who suffered from a number of medical conditions including seizures. The divorced mother and Kelly later became friends and often socialised together. The social care graduate attacked her at her home, however, after she allegedly made "derogatory" remarks about his children. Kelly grabbed Ms Beattie and strangled her before leaving the flat. He later returned and on finding her dead sat with her body before moving it to her bed before fleeing. The court was told Kelly took a train to Edinburgh having used Ms Beattie's bank card to steal Â£300 from his victim's bank account. The victim's body

It follows Alec Leamas, a hard-drinking British intelligence officer whose East Berlin network is in tatters. Le Carre said he was "very excited" by the show, which will appear on BBC One. The series will be another co-production with US network AMC, following their joint effort on The Night Manager. Tom Hiddleston, Hugh Laurie and Olivia Colman all won Golden Globes for their roles in the drama, while the show itself was nominated for best mini series or TV film at the awards. The Spy Who Came In From The Cold is set in 1962, months after the building of the Berlin Wall. Julia Knight, 56, denies attempting to murder Irene Robson, 81, at Horton Hospital in Banbury in October 2014, but admits to causing grievous bodily harm. Knight, a former nurse, was charged in connection to an incident involving her elderly patient, Irene Robson, at Horton Hospital in Banbury in October 2014. She is accused of administering a non-prescribed dosage of drugs, leading to a significant deterioration in Robson's health.

Knight, however, maintains her innocence, vehemently denying the accusation of attempted murder. She does, however, admit to causing harm, albeit unintentionally. The defense argues Knight's actions were a result of professional negligence, not a premeditated attempt to end a life.

The case has sent shockwaves through the medical community in Banbury, reigniting debates on patient safety and the heavy responsibility healthcare professionals bear. The trial continues at the Oxford Crown Court, where Knight faces possible conviction. The outcome of the case is being closely watched, not just by those directly involved, but also by professionals in the healthcare sector nationwide.

original: NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) said blood group O negative was vital, as it could be used for patients with other blood groups in an emergency. It said O negative blood made up 12% of transfers, although only 7% of people in the UK had that blood type. Meanwhile, B negative blood is needed for ethnic groups. The NHSBT said ethnic minority groups, who were more likely to have B negative blood, were more prone to sickle cell anaemia, where misshapen blood cells could block blood vessels, causing an early death. It also said such groups were more at risk of developing thalassemia, a group of inherited blood disorders that hindered the blood's ability to carry oxygen. Only 2% of Britain's population were B negative, but hospitals had used 6% more of this blood type in the past last four weeks than the same period last year, said the NHSBT. B negative blood was useful as it could be used for both B negative and B positive patients,
variant_1: NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) emphasized the importance of O negative blood because it can be transfused to patients of any blood group during emergencies. Despite only 7% of the UK population having O negative blood, it accounts for 12% of blood transfers. In addition, B negative blood is particularly needed for ethnic minority groups. NHSBT noted that people from these groups, who are more likely to possess B negative blood, have a higher risk of sickle cell anaemia, a condition where abnormally shaped blood cells can obstruct blood vessels and lead to premature death. They are also more susceptible to thalassemia, inherited disorders that reduce blood's oxygen-carrying capacity. Though B negative blood is rare, found in only 2% of the UK population, hospitals used 6% more B negative blood in the previous four weeks compared to the same timeframe last year, according to NHSBT. Charles Blackman's oil work Women Lovers features two nude women resting on a bed beside a cat. Art broker Mossgreen attempted to promote this intricate piece in an effort to highlight the emotional depth of Blackman's work. The painting, characterized by its expressive strokes and muted tones, is thought to be one of Blackman's more intimate depictions of the human form. 

This particular artwork has long been admired for its tender portrayal of affection between women, a theme not often explored in the mid-20th century. The cat, a recurring motif in Blackman's work, adds an element of mystery and intrigue. 

Blackman's fascination with the dynamics of relationships and the complexity of human emotions is brilliantly echoed in this oil painting. This promotion by Mossgreen was not just an attempt to sell an artwork, but an endeavor to showcase the depth and sensitivity of Blackman's vision. original: Thomas, 28, is a key member of the Team Sky side trying to guide Chris Froome to a second successive Tour title. Froome has already been sent for an X-ray after a crash during the fourth stage of the Tour de France. "On the cobbles it's sketchy anyway. If it does rain it could end somebody's race quite easily," said Thomas. "You train all year for this and for it to end like that would be devastating for whoever it was. "So hopefully it stays dry and everyone stays out of trouble." Froome touched wheels in the peloton and fell just five kilometres into the 163.5km fourth stage between Le Touquet-Paris-Place and Lille Metropole. The 29-year-old suffered a grazed left hip and wrist injury, before quickly getting back on his bike and rejoining the peloton, after receiving medical attention from the race doctor. He is in seventh place overall, two seconds behind race leader Vincenzo Nibali after stage four was won by Marcel Kittel. Wednesday's stage begins in the Belgian city of Ypres and ends 155.5km away in Arenberg-Porte

original:
Aiden Webb, 22, from Norwich, set off to climb the Fansipan Mountain alone on 3 June. He called his girlfriend to say he had fallen and injured himself, sparking a frantic search for him in the rugged Vietnamese terrain. Webb is a seasoned adventurer, known for his prowess in outdoor sports and mountain climbing, making the news of his accident all the more shocking to those who know him.

His girlfriend, Bluebell Baughan, immediately alerted the authorities, sparking a search and rescue operation that spanned several days. Tragically, Webb's body was discovered by local search teams on Tuesday, ending the desperate search. Aiden was known for his love of nature, outdoor adventure, and his vibrant spirit. His untimely death has left a deep void in the global outdoor adventure community.

His family and girlfriend are devastated but grateful for the outpouring of support from the public. The British consulate is providing consular support to his family and working with local authorities

original: Research for the College of Policing suggested that officers were focusing on cases involving violence and overlooking other risk factors. Three unnamed police forces in England and Wales are taking part in a pilot scheme following the study. Coercive or controlling behaviour became a criminal offence last year. The research found that although most domestic abuse incidents were handled in a "professional" way, some officers still displayed "negative and uninformed" attitudes. In particular, police tended to neglect cases where suspects did not use violence but tried to control their victim in other ways such as by making threats. The report said: "A tendency for the police to focus on physical violence and what has occurred at the current incident can result in them missing abuse which is characterised not by physical violence and injury but by continuous coercion and control in other forms." The researchers concluded that if risk was not assessed properly some cases would "slip through the net". In response, the College of Policing is setting up a pilot scheme to help officers identify possible patterns of abusive behaviour. David Tucker, the college's lead

original:
The new charity will manage the National Heritage Collection, which includes iconic historical sites such as Stonehenge and Dover Castle. The government currently contributes £22m annually towards the upkeep and conservation of these sites of national significance. 

The charity, set to take over from the government, has promised to maintain the integrity of these historical markers and increase their accessibility to the public. The change in management hopes to bring a renewed focus on community engagement, education, and historical preservation. 

The government's annual contribution will continue under the new arrangement, ensuring the longevity and preservation of the National Heritage Collection. The charity plans to supplement this funding with private donations, corporate sponsorships, and revenue from increased visitor numbers. 

This development signals an exciting new era for the National Heritage Collection, offering a fresh perspective on the management of these treasured sites, while ensuring they continue to hold a proud place in Britain’s cultural landscape.

original: Maj Richard Scott, 40, is accused of driving at speeds of up to 95mph (153km/h) in bad weather before the smash on a B-road in Wiltshire. Gareth Hicks, 24, suffered fatal injuries when the van he was asleep in was hit by Mr Scott's Audi A6. Maj Scott denies a charge of causing death by careless driving. Prosecutor Charles Gabb alleged the defendant, from Green Lane in Shepperton, Surrey, had crossed the carriageway of the 60mph-limit B390 in Shrewton near Amesbury. The weather was "awful" and there was strong wind and rain, he told jurors. He said Mr Scott's car was described as "twitching" and "may have been aquaplaning" before striking the first vehicle; a BMW driven by Craig Reed. Mr Scott's Audi then returned to his side of the road but crossed the carriageway again before colliding head-on with a Ford Transit van in which Mr Hicks was a passenger, the

The proposals are believed to include tougher English language requirements for students. Dominic Scott, head of the UK Council for International Student Affairs, said it would be a significant step forward in elevating the quality of international education in the UK. The proposals are believed to include tougher English language requirements for students. This move comes in response to concerns that some international students lack sufficient English proficiency to fully engage in their chosen academic courses.

Scott stated, "Higher English proficiency standards can ensure students not only succeed acadically but also integrate better into the local community and culture." Critics argue that the move could deter potential students from applying to UK universities. However, Scott countered that it will attract students genuinely interested in improving their language skills and learning.

The proposal forms part of a wider government initiative to uphold the integrity and quality of UK higher education amidst increasing global competition. It's hoped that these changes might also encourage UK students to consider studying foreign languages, fostering a more global outlook in the nation's youth. The proposal is yet to receive final approval and is currently under review.

original:
The furry feline has been a familiar face on the steps outside Number 10's black door since he moved in, in 2011. And the nation's beloved cat, Larry, has not only become a beloved figure in his own right, but an emblem of political stability amidst years of political turbulence. 

This charismatic Chief Mouser has witnessed the comings and goings of three prime ministers, adding an amusing and heartwarming fixture to the often high-tension world of politics. Larry, a brown and white tabby, was recruited from Battersea Dogs & Cats Home with a clear mission: to keep Downing Street pest-free. 

However, his duties have expanded over the years to include photo ops, greeting guests, and appearing on international television. His fame has spread far beyond the UK, with fans across the globe following his antics via social media updates. Larry proves that even in the midst of political upheaval, a furry friend can provide comfort and continuity.

Her mother complained about her treatment to the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC). Sussex Police said it welcomed the IPCC scrutiny and supported its inquiry. The girl came into contact with police between 2 February and 2 March last year in Horsham, West Sussex. She was held under under the mental health act on 9 February, arrested on suspicion of assault seven days later, held over a public order offence on 29 February and arrested in connection with criminal damage on 2 March. The girl's mother complained in July 2012 about the methods of restraint used on her daughter, which the IPCC said appeared to have included handcuffs and leg restraints, and the decisions to hold her in police cells overnight. The Port Talbot-based Specific innovation centre is working on the concept of "buildings as power stations". The project involves Tata Steel, Swansea University and AkzoNobel. 

The Port Talbot-based Specific Innovation Centre is working on the revolutionary concept of "buildings as power stations". An ambitious project, it is a collaborative effort involving Tata Steel, Swansea University and AkzoNobel, aiming to create a sustainable future for the construction industry.

At its core, the project aims to develop buildings that can generate, store, and release their own solar energy. This innovative approach to energy production and consumption could transform the way we perceive and use buildings.

Tata Steel provides the building materials, Swansea University brings its expertise in solar energy research, while AkzoNobel, a global paint and coatings company, ensures the buildings are not only energy efficient but aesthetically pleasing as well.

The Specific innovation Centre's project offers a glimpse into a sustainable future where buildings contribute to energy production rather than being solely consumers of it. It marks a significant step towards a greener and more sustainable construction sector, providing a model that could be replicated worldwide

Mrs Foster said on Wednesday that she wanted to better understand those who love the language. She said she wanted to "listen to and engage with those who love the language" in reference to her new initiative aimed at promoting cultural diversity and inclusivity.

Mrs Foster said on Wednesday that she wanted to better understand those who love the language. She said she wanted to "listen to and engage with those who use, promote, and cherish the language every day." This statement marks a significant shift in her previously held stance, signaling a more inclusive approach to understanding and appreciating the cultural and linguistic diversity within our community.

The initiative, dubbed "Listening to Languages", is expected to involve several engagement activities, including language workshops, cultural exchange programs, and public forums, geared towards promoting understanding and respect for all languages and cultures.

In her announcement, Mrs. Foster emphasized, "The love for language transcends borders and barriers. It is our collective responsibility to understand, respect and celebrate this diversity. I hope this initiative will foster a new appreciation for the richness language brings to our lives."

original:
Unemployment fell to 1.69 million between January and March, down 2,000 from the previous quarter. The jobless rate remained at 4.9%, according to the latest figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). This static rate reflects the stability in the UK job market, despite ongoing economic uncertainties. 

The numbers signify that the UK economy continues to display resilience, maintaining a relatively low level of unemployment. Economists have noted the robustness of the job market, attributing it to a combination of flexible working arrangements and sustained consumer spending. 

However, experts have also pointed out that while the overall unemployment figures are positive, they do not explicitly reflect the quality of work available. Underemployment and the prevalence of zero-hour contracts are ongoing issues, which the headline figures fail to address. 

These statistics underpin the complex reality of the job market, which, while demonstrating overall strength and stability, also reveals areas that require significant improvement. Further investigation into improving employment quality, not just quantity, is needed to assure a truly healthy economy.

original: The walk-in service is aimed at reducing doctor appointments and to help reduce the over-use of antibiotics, NHS England said. It is hoped the scheme could result in fewer visits to GPs -potentially saving the NHS millions of pounds a year. But pharmacies say cuts in funding to the sector could jeopardise the scheme. The Sore Throat Test and Treat service, which has been trialled in 35 Boots pharmacies, will determine if an illness is caused by a virus - meaning drugs will not help - or a bacterial infection. Results from a throat swab, which measures sugars on the tongue, are provided in five minutes. Patients who can be helped by antibiotics will be prescribed them by the pharmacist and not have to see a GP. NHS chief executive Simon Stevens said the scheme will be rolled out across the country over the coming year. original: A survey of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Fewer than one in 10 took more than their two weeks statutory leave. The research by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) blamed "ingrained" attitudes among employers, and concerns among new fathers that they could not afford to take leave. Last year the government announced plans to allow parents to share their maternity and paternity leave - changes are scheduled to come in April 2015. But the ILM said its research suggested the changes would have little impact if attitudes of employers were not addressed as well. "The introduction of shared parental leave is a crucial step towards enabling more women to progress into senior roles," said Charles Elvin, ILM chief executive. "Yet our research revealed cultural barriers are impeding the uptake of both two weeks statutory paternity leave and additional paternity leave." He said there remained a "cultural expectation" within organisations that women rather than men will be the ones taking extended periods away from the workplace. The report also said low levels of paternity pay discouraged new fathers,
variant_1: A survey conducted among employees and managers revealed that 25% of new fathers did not take any paternity leave. Less than 10% took more than the mandatory two weeks of leave. Research by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) attributed this to deep-rooted employer attitudes and new fathers' financial concerns about taking leave. The government announced plans last year to allow parents to share maternity and paternity leave, with changes set for April 2015. However, ILM warned these changes might have minimal effect unless employer attitudes also evolve. Charles Elvin, ILM CEO, commented that shared parental leave is vital for advancing women into senior roles, but cultural obstacles limit the use of both statutory and additional paternity leave. A "cultural expectation" persists that women, not men, are the primary caregivers during extended absences. The report also highlighted that low paternity pay discourages new fathers from taking leave.

original: Scot Higgins, 19, started his youth career at Celtic before moving to Dens Park and made four appearances for Dundee last season. Former Republish of Ireland Under-21 player Power, 29, leaves English League Two club Lincoln City, where he made over 250 league appearances. Both players have agreed two-year contracts with the Rugby Park club, with Power's move subject to clearance. "It feels good to be here, as it's a club that's definitely going in the right direction," Higgins told Kilmarnock's website. Manager Lee McCulloch said Higgins fits Kilmarnock's philosophy of developing young players. "He came through Celtic's academy, which has seen many impressive young players come through," said McCulloch. "For the second half of last season he gained experience at Dundee and through time will only get better, which is only a good thing for this club." And Power said: "I've heard a lot about the town and the club's history and I can't wait to get started. The manager spoke about his visions for this club and it was an easy decision to make." McCulloch said he watch Lincoln's run to the quarter-finals of the FA

Maj Richard Scott, 40, is accused of driving at speeds of up to 95mph (153km/h) in bad weather before the shocking accident that resulted in severe injuries to a pedestrian late last Tuesday. The incident occurred along a notorious stretch of the M4 highway, renowned for treacherous conditions during heavy rainfall. Police reports suggest that Scott, a decorated military officer, lost control of his vehicle due to excessive speed and poor visibility, striking a 52-year-old man who was immediately rushed to the hospital in critical condition. 

The Major now faces potential charges of reckless driving and causing serious bodily harm. He was released on bail awaiting a court hearing. The accident has prompted local authorities to reconsider safety measures on the M4, including the possibility of lowering speed limits during inclement weather. This tragic accident serves as a stark reminder of the vital importance of road safety, particularly in adverse weather conditions.

Remus Hamza, 40, is alleged to have attacked a 20-year-old woman near Cardiff University as she walked home alone after a night out. The incident, which reportedly took place at the end of last week, has sent shockwaves through the local community and university campus.

The victim, whose identity has been kept anonymous for her protection, was thankfully able to escape the ordeal without life-threatening injuries. However, she is said to be in a state of trauma following the incident. Local authorities were alerted and quickly initiated an investigation.

Hamza was arrested on charges of sexual assault and public intoxication. As of now, he remains in police custody, awaiting a court hearing.

This incident has spurred discussions about safety, particularly for female students in the area. Cardiff University and local police are said to be stepping up security measures on and around the campus to ensure the well-being of its students. Students are being advised to be more vigilant and take necessary precautions while out at night.

A train travelling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train on platform six just after 15.30 BST on 3 April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch is currently investigating the incident.

A train travelling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train on platform six just after 15.30 BST on 3 April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch has been called in to understand the circumstances leading to the crash. The collision occurred at lower speed, resulting in minor structural damage to both trains but no significant injuries to passengers or crew.

British Transport Police and local emergency services responded promptly, evacuating the station and rerouting incoming trains. As a result, significant delays and disruptions were experienced throughout the network.

The station has been closed temporarily until a thorough inspection is completed to ensure the tracks' safety. The train company apologised to all passengers affected by the incident and promised to conduct a full investigation.

A spokesperson for the Rail Accident Investigation Branch said, "Our team is working diligently to establish the causes of this incident, and we will provide updates as our investigation progresses." The results of this investigation could lead to new safety protocols to

Falcon and Pointer was fined £175,000 for making automated calls about PPI, and Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd was fined £50,000 for nuisance calls. This comes as part of a continuing clamping down by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) on companies breaching privacy laws. Falcon and Pointer were accused of making over 2.5 million automated calls about PPI claims, causing significant distress and annoyance to the recipients. In fact, the ICO received 5,535 complaints about the company's practices. 

Similarly, Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd was hit with a hefty fine following 168 complaints about unsolicited marketing calls made to people who had specifically opted out of receiving such communications. The ICO is showing its commitment to protect the privacy and rights of individuals from companies that disregard the law. These fines should serve as a stark warning to other companies engaging in similar practices - they could be next in the ICO's line of fire. The public is advised to report any nuisance calls to the ICO.

Mr Hunt wants to change junior doctors' contracts, which he says are "unfair". The BMA said its door was open to talks and blamed the strikes on Mr Hunt's "shambolic mishandling" of the matter. The dispute, which began in 2014 and centres around pay and weekend working, has led to strikes being held across England. The next is a 24-hour strike planned for Wednesday, when emergency care will only be provided from 08:00 GMT. Asking by Marr about low morale among junior doctors, Mr Hunt said: "One of the reasons for that anger is that they were told by the BMA that their pay was going to be cut - it isn't. "They were told that they were going to be asked to work longer hours - they aren't," he added. "We are actually bringing down the hours that they work. original:
The Crawick Multiverse, designed by renowned artist Charles Jencks, has been created with materials found on the site in Dumfries and Galloway. 

The Crawick Multiverse, designed by renowned artist Charles Jencks, has been created with materials found on the site in Dumfries and Galloway. This large scale public art installation, sprawled over 55 acres, is a riveting blend of science, art, and landscape design. It showcases Jenck's unique vision, transforming what was once a deserted coal mine into an astonishing testament to the mysteries of the cosmos. 

The site features a myriad of sculptures and landforms, symbolizing cosmic concepts and scientific theories. Highlights include the Multiverse, the Comet Walk, and representations of black holes. These are all constructed using stones, earth and other materials found on site, reflecting Jencks' commitment to sustainability and environmental harmony.

The last print edition will be on 31 December, reflecting the trend for newspapers and magazines to move online as traditional advertising declines. Newsweek merged with the The Daily Beast in 2010.

The last print edition will be on 31 December, reflecting the trend for newspapers and magazines to move online as traditional advertising declines. Newsweek merged with the Daily Beast in 2010 in an attempt to consolidate resources and expand its digital presence. The decision to end the print edition marks another milestone in the industry's shift towards digital media. The move comes amid the steady decline of print circulation and advertising revenue, a challenge that has been confronting the publishing industry for years. 

Newsweek plans to continue publishing digital versions of its magazine, focusing on its online subscription model while still delivering the quality journalism it is known for.

The shift to digital reflects the reality of our digital-first world and the changing consumer behavior. While this decision might disappoint print-version lovers, it’s a necessary adaptation for the survival and growth of media institutions in this digital era. Newsweek, in its new avatar, aims to continue to inform, engage and inspire readers around the world.

original: The furry feline has been a familiar face on the steps outside Number 10's black door since he moved in, in 2011. And the "chief mouser" will stay when Theresa May replaces Mr Cameron as UK prime minister. "It's a civil servant's cat and does not belong to the Camerons - he will be staying," a government spokesman said. The tabby cat, from London's Battersea Cats and Dogs Home, was brought in to Downing Street in 2011 tasked with tackling a rat problem, after a large black rat was seen scuttling past the No 10's front door in the background of a live TV broadcast. Said to have a "strong predatory drive" and enjoy playing with mouse toys, Larry was considered to be well-suited to the post.
