original: Gabon was selected as host on Wednesday by the Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee, beating rival candidates Ghana and Algeria. "We will prepare ourselves to win the Nations Cup in 2017," said Gabon football official Jean-Felix Mba Nze. "We have decided to play and win the cup." Gabon first entered the Nations Cup in 1970 but failed to qualify for the finals until 1994. Their best results came when reaching the quarter-finals in 1996 and 2012, a tournament they co-hosted with Equatorial Guinea. During this year's Nations Cup, which also took place in Equatorial Guinea, the Panthers crashed out early after winning one and losing two of their group games. The 2017 Nations Cup will be the first time Gabon has staged the finals by itself. The successful launch of the KSLV-1, also known as Naro, underpins South Korea's ambitious plans to become a major player in the multibillion-dollar space industry.

original: The cut, which took the markets by surprise, was the first since 2012, and comes into effect on Saturday. The one-year lending rate will also be reduced from 6% to 5.6%. On Thursday figures showed China's factory output contracting for the first time in six months. Economic growth slowed to a five-year low of 7.3% last quarter. Many economists had expected China to stimulate economic growth through fiscal spending rather than lowering rates. To offset the effect of lower rates on savers the bank said it would give banks the flexibility to offer higher deposit rates, up to 1.2 times the benchmark level, rather than 1.1 times. Shares in mining companies jumped by 3-4% after the cut on the hope that better growth would help sales of raw materials to China. Shares in Rio Tinto surged 3.9% percent and BHP Billiton rose 2.9%. The Australian and New Zealand currencies also strengthened reflecting their dependence on trade with China. President Xi Jinping told chief executives at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit

original: The 10 trees have been nominated by members of the public for the competition run by the Woodland Trust charity. A public vote will decide the winner for England's 'Tree of the Year' award. This annual contest, run by the Woodland Trust charity, celebrates and recognizes the importance and beauty of the country's oldest, most varied, and often most overlooked natural monuments. This year’s nominees include a 500-year-old Mulberry tree in Buckinghamshire, a historic Oak in Cornwall, and a rare Elm in Brighton. Each tree carries its unique narrative, making the competition not only a celebration of nature, but also of heritage and history. The public vote aims to raise awareness about the preservation of these natural heritages. The winning tree will represent the nation in the European Tree of the Year contest next year. Voting will remain open until September 24 and the winner will be announced in October. The Woodland Trust encourages everyone to participate in this celebration of nature's magnificent giants.

original: Spencer Flower claimed his involvement with a social housing company was not relevant to a debate in 2013 over the future of housing in east Dorset. But he was found guilty of voting illegally as the firm could have benefitted from the plan being passed. The Conservative councillor, 72, will be allowed to remain in public office. Flower, of Verwood, Dorset, was given a six-month conditional discharge and ordered to pay Â£930 costs. A district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court ruled he had broken laws under the Localism Act 2011. Speaking outside court, Flower refused to comment on his political future. He said: "I am surprised and disappointed that the court has found for the prosecution this morning on a technicality. "The decision was a conditional discharge for six months - the lowest possible penalty. "The court emphasised the total lack of any personal gain or intent on my part." Flower, who is also an East Dorset councillor, voted in February 2013 on East Dorset's core strategy while non-executive director of charitable social housing company

original:
Buckingham Palace announced on Friday evening that the Queen would not attend because she had gastroenteritis. Lord Lieutenant of West Glamorgan Byron Lewis, who was supposed to accompany the Queen to the event, expressed his well wishes for her quick recovery. 

Buckingham Palace announced on Friday evening that the Queen would not attend because she had gastroenteritis. The Queen, who had been scheduled to attend a series of engagements in Swansea, Wales, was advised by her doctors to rest. Lord Lieutenant of West Glamorgan, Byron Lewis, who was due to accompany the Queen at the event, empathised with her situation, stating, "Her Majesty's health comes first. We wish her a swift recovery."

Gastroenteritis is an inflammation of the stomach and intestines, usually resulting from bacterial toxins or viral infection and causing vomiting and diarrhea. Palace officials assured the public that the Queen is being well taken care of and is in good spirits despite her illness.

In light of this situation, the palace has not announced any changes to the Queen's schedule for the upcoming week. People across the nation are sending their best wishes to the Queen

original: A report from British Marine, which represents the leisure, superyacht and small commercial marine industry, said superyacht revenues for the year to April 2016 had reached £605m. Revenues for the whole sector rose 1.6% to £3.01bn, the first time the £3bn mark has been breached since 2008-2009. However, the report predicted growth would slow during 2017. It said uncertainty over Brexit negotiations was likely to curb demand. Total revenue fell in the wake of financial crisis, reaching its lowest point in the financial year 2011-2012 of £2,85bn and has been gradually picking up since then. Increased revenue from engine and equipment manufacturing, as well as a jump in sales of hire and charter boats, are believed to have driven the sales increase. Exports for the year were down 0.7% to £882m but British Marine said that in the last few months the industry had benefited from the fall

original: S4C gets most of its income from the licence fee and UK ministers have announced a major review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies told BBC Wales S4C was a "special case as it promotes the Welsh language". Ministers have said S4C should aim for similar cost savings as the BBC. On Thursday, Labour warned that cuts to the BBC's budget threatened S4C, but Culture Secretary John Whittingdale told MPs there was a commitment to the channel "within the next couple of years", and he hoped to have discussions with its management in the near future. Mr Davies told BBC Radio Cymru's Rhaglen Dylan Jones, on Friday: "The government realise the importance of S4C and that it's more than a station, it's important to the future of the Welsh language." Mr Davies also hinted that the Welsh Affairs Committee, which he chairs, could consider conducting an inquiry into broadcasting, including S4C. "These are personal views but

original:
The Swiss bank said US regulators were investigating potential sales of so called "bearer bonds". These bonds can be transferred without registering ownership, enabling wealthy owners to potentially evade tax obligations. 

The Swiss bank said US regulators were investigating potential sales of so-called "bearer bonds". These bonds can be transferred without registering ownership, enabling wealthy individuals to potentially dodge tax obligations. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) are reportedly leading the probe, which could hold significant implications for global finance. 

Bearer bonds, which were outlawed in the US in 1982 due to their use in money laundering and tax evasion, are still legal in other countries, including Switzerland. Critics argue that these unregistered securities are a loophole in tax law that primarily benefits the ultra-wealthy. 

The investigation comes amid increased efforts by US authorities to crack down on offshore tax evasion. The Swiss bank, which has not been named, could face severe penalties if found guilty of facilitating tax evasion through the sale of bearer bonds. The bank has not offered any comment on the investigation as of yet.

Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The Unesco World Heritage Site, The Giant's Causeway, was the first stop on a day filled with public engagements for the duo. Located in County Antrim, the world-renowned site is a geological marvel, celebrated for its distinctive hexagonal basalt columns, formed millions of years ago by volcanic activity. 

During the visit, they engaged with passionate locals and dedicated conservationists to discuss the ongoing preservation efforts and the importance of maintaining this site as a beacon of geological significance. They also learned how this natural wonder continues to play a critical role in the area's tourism industry. 

While there, they were also treated to a display of local cultural heritage, including traditional music and dance performances, providing a vivid example of the rich cultural legacy of County Antrim. 

The visit emphasized their commitment to supporting both the natural and cultural treasures of the regions they visit, showcasing the important balance between conservation and cultural heritage.

original: Matthew Eteson is on trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, 36, and Lauren Thornton. The pair died in their sleep aboard a boat on Windermere in April 2013. Mr Eteson, 42, from Hale in Greater Manchester, denies the charge. The family had gone to the Lake District for the Easter bank holiday weekend to celebrate a friend's birthday. But on the afternoon of 1 April, Mr Eteson removed the generator from the deck and used it to power a 1kW fan heater to heat the sleeping quarter, prosecutor Mr Graham Reeds QC said. The court was told that there had been no warning to the build-up of the toxic gas because the carbon monoxide sensors had previously been disabled. Mr Reeds said the mother and daughter, both from Leyland in Lancashire, were found dead in their sleeping positions aboard the the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor

original: The fragile piece of wood is all that remains of the Nanteos Cup, a wooden chalice named after the mansion in Aberystwyth where it was once kept. Some believe it was the cup from which Christ drank at the Last Supper and that it has healing powers. It was stolen in 2014 before being returned to its owners a year later. It has now been donated to the library in Aberystwyth where thousands of people are expected to view it over the coming months. Pedr ap Llwyd, director of collections and public programmes, said visitors would finally be able to view the "mysterious object". "This is truly a remarkable object and a very interesting addition to the national collections." The cup is claimed to have been brought to Britain by Joseph of Arimathea after the death of Christ and then taken to Nanteos Mansion by seven monks from Strata Florida, Ceredigion, during the reign of Henry Vlll. The house was then owned by the Powell family and, after the monks died, they took possession of

The lioness, dubbed 'Mother Theresa of the Animal Kingdom,' was seen suckling a leopard cub estimated to be just three weeks old. Experts claim it is rare for a lioness to nurse another's offspring, let alone from another species. The country's Chamber of Deputies had already approved the legislation. The vote in the Senate, which backed the bill by just six votes, came after an intense and lengthy debate that extended into the early hours of the morning. This confirms a decisive step towards the enforcement of the controversial legislation, which has been a subject of heated discussions across the nation.

The bill, which seeks to overhaul the existing laws in a bid to drive economic growth and social equality, has been met with fierce opposition and large-scale protests. Critics argue that the changes could infrally infringe on civil liberties, while supporters maintain it will bring about much-needed reform.

Despite the controversy, the slim majority in the Senate has paved the way for the bill to be passed into law. It is expected that the President will sign it into action within the week. This historic decision marks a turning point in the legislative landscape, signaling a new era in national politics.

original:
Regina Hungerford, 56, denied striking a 17-year-old as he listened to music in her class at Merthyr Tydfil College. The veteran teacher, who is highly respected among colleagues, stands accused of misconduct during a vocational training session. She allegedly smacked the teenager on the back of his head when he refused to remove his headphones and pay attention to the ongoing lesson.

Hungerford, however, fervently contests the accusation, insisting that she only "tapped" the student in a bid to grab his attention. According to her testimony, she used no force and certainly no intent to harm the student. 

The police were informed about the incident following a report from the college. After a thorough investigation, they concluded that there was insufficient evidence to pursue a criminal prosecution. The case has now moved to the hands of the Education Workforce Council, which will ultimately decide the fate of Hungerford's teaching career. 

The incident has sparked a lively local debate on teacher

original: The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, which translates as "fuel shortage in a film", became France's top Twitter trend on Tuesday, with more than 5,000 tweets. A strike over new labour laws is now affecting all of France's eight oil refineries. An estimated 20% of petrol stations have either run dry or are low on supplies. In their posts, French social media users talk about films such as Total Recall, the title of both a 1990 and 2012 science fiction film. Total is also the name of a French multinational oil and gas company. Some users also changed film titles to reflect the shortage: Pulp Fiction was renamed Pump Friction, The Full Monty became The Fuel Monty and Mad Max: Fury Bicycle Lane replaced Mad Max: Fury Road. American actor Vin Diesel's surname and his Hollywood blockbusters attracted particular attention, with people inventing several titles for his Fast and Furious series: Last and Furious, Pas Fast Mais Furious (translation: Not Fast But Furious),

original: The care at Stafford Hospital left some patients drinking water from vases, it is claimed, and receptionists assessing emergency cases. Julie Bailey, who founded the Cure the NHS group after the death of her mother at the hospital in 2007, said that the levels of neglect were horrifying. She related stories of starving patients forced to eat from bins, and of those left in agony as overworked nurses failed to administer medication. Perhaps most concerning was the revelation that unqualified receptionists were often left to evaluate patients in emergency cases. A report into the scandal, published in 2013, found that between 400 and 1,200 patients may have died unnecessarily due to subpar care. The damning evidence has led to a national conversation about healthcare standards in the UK, and about the systemic failings that can lead to such a disaster. Bailey continues to fight for justice and reform, insisting that nothing short of a complete overhaul of the system will prevent the same issues from recurring in the future.

original: Erika Murray, 31, was arrested on Thursday night after a neighbour alerted police over the safety of other children living at the house. Detectives found the bodies in what they described as a squalid, vermin-infested home. On Friday Ms Murray pleaded not guilty to all charges. Those include foetal death concealment, witness intimidation and permitting substantial injury to a child. Her lawyer said he believed she suffered with mental illness. "You want answers in circumstances like this... mental illness doesn't always provide those kinds of answers," Ms Murray's lawyer Keith Halpern said after her court appearance. Police were first called to the home in Blackstone when a neighbour was approached by one of the children living there, said Tim Connolly, a spokesman for the Worcester district attorney. The ten-year boy is reported to have asked the neighbour, "How do you get a baby to stop crying?" The neighbour went with the boy and found the crying

original: Heading the processions were some of those caught up in the suicide bomb attacks on Belgium's airport and metro station that killed 32 people. Belgian broadcaster described the march as "calm and silent". The march had been due to be held a week after the 22 March attacks, but officials asked for it to be postponed because of the security threat. Relatives of victims, and paramedics and airport staff affected by the attacks joined people of several religious faiths on Sunday's march. Flowers were carried in memory of those who lost their lives. The procession took them past the Molenbeek neighbourhood - where many of those alleged to have carried out the attacks in both Brussels and Paris had lived - and to the makeshift memorial outside the city's stock exchange. One of the organisers of the march, Hassan Bousetta, told the AFP news agency: "When our fellow citizens, defenceless civilians, are cut down in a cowardly attack, all citizens should stand up to express their disgust and solidarity." The turnout was less than half of the 15,000 organisers had hoped for. The attacks

original:
New shots of Charlene Downes, 14, who was last seen in Blackpool town centre, were discovered during a trawl of CCTV. The images surfaced nearly two decades after the teenager went missing, reigniting hope in the ongoing investigation. 

Downes vanished without a trace on November 1, 2003, sparking one of the most extensive missing person cases in the history of Lancashire Police. Despite numerous appeals, her whereabouts remained a mystery. The newly discovered CCTV footage shows Charlene walking towards the Coral Island complex at around 3:35 pm on the day she disappeared. 

The discovery has provided a significant breakthrough in the cold case. Lancashire Police stated, "This could potentially lead to new information that is crucial for our investigation." The police are now appealing for anyone who was in the vicinity of Coral Island on the day Charlene disappeared to come forward. The family continues to live in hope that they will one day find closure in this heart-wrenching case.

original:
England have been hit by injuries in the back row, with James Haskell, Sam Jones and Mike Williams all ruled out, along with the versatile Tom Wood. This has left coach Eddie Jones scrambling for options before their Six Nations championship clash against Scotland. 

The RFU confirmed on Monday that Haskell, Jones, Williams, and Wood have all picked up injuries during training. Haskell and Williams suffered foot injuries, Sam Jones sustained a fractured leg, while Wood is nursing a shoulder injury. 

The injury crisis is a huge blow for England, who have been enjoying a solid run in the Six Nations Championship. This comes as an unexpected disruption to their preparation, which had been focused on maintaining their unbeaten run in the championship. 

Despite the setback, Coach Eddie Jones seemed optimistic. "We have depth in the squad, which will allow other players to step up," he said. 

But with a strong Scottish side lying in wait, the four absentees will undoubtedly be a significant loss. Only time will tell if England can maintain their winning momentum without their key back row players.

original: Kevin Mcleod's body was found in Wick harbour in February 1997. The 24-year-old's death was treated as accidental, but his family believe that injuries on his body showed that he was murdered. An assessment was done of "all information known" regarding the death after contact between his family and chief constable Phil Gormley. Police said the review had included tracing and speaking to people who were in Wick the night Mr Mcleod died, but who had not previously come forward. Mr Mcleod's mother, June, told BBC Scotland last month that if the assessment "turned up nothing new" she and her family would continue to fight for a fresh investigation. original:
The bodies of backpackers Miss Witheridge, 23, from Norfolk, and Mr Miller, 24, from Jersey, were found on a beach in the popular tourist destination, the Koh Tao island in Thailand. The pair, who were traveling separately, met at a local hotel where they were staying.

The local authorities discovered their bodies early Monday morning, following a beach party the previous night. Both had suffered severe head injuries and, according to initial police reports, appeared to be victims of a savage attack.

Their deaths have sent shockwaves through the international backpacking community, leading to an outpouring of condolences and calls for increased safety measures for young travelers in foreign countries. The British embassy in Bangkok is providing support to the grieving families and working closely with Thai police to expedite the ongoing investigation.

The tragic incident has also triggered a significant decline in tourism to Koh Tao, known as a paradise for divers, reflecting the growing concerns over the safety of tourists in the region.

original:
Research for the College of Policing suggested that officers were focusing on cases involving violence and overlooking other risk factors. Three unnamed police forces in England and Wales have been identified in a recent research study conducted by the College of Policing. The findings suggest that officers were primarily focusing on cases involving violence and overlooking other significant risk factors. This bias towards violent offences may be compromising the efficacy of policing in these areas, potentially leaving citizens vulnerable to other types of crime.

The research highlighted the need for deeper insights and broader scopes in threat assessments to ensure comprehensive law enforcement. The three unnamed police forces have reportedly taken the findings on board and are now reassessing their approaches to address this issue.

The findings also urge for improved training and resource allocation, particularly for areas of crime that may not involve violence but are equally detrimental, such as cybercrime, fraud, and drug offenses. The College of Policing hopes that this research can provide an impetus for change, not just within the three forces investigated, but across all forces, improving the overall standard of public safety.

The study calls for broader threat assessments and advises the forces to adjust their methods accordingly. Furthermore, the findings highlight the need for better training and resources, especially for non-violent crimes like cybercrime, fraud, and drug offenses. The College of Policing hopes the research will drive improvements beyond the three forces involved, enhancing overall public safety standards.

Additionally, it underscores the importance of investing in training and resources for non-violent yet harmful crimes such as cybercrime and fraud. The College hopes these findings motivate change both within the identified forces and more widely across policing agencies.

Sterling rose 1.86% against the dollar to $1.32.40, and was 1.73% higher against the euro, marking its strongest performance in over a year. This surge has been attributed to a combination of factors, including continued post-Brexit optimism and stronger than anticipated economic data.

Analysts attribute the bullish sentiment around the sterling to the recent release of robust UK employment figures, which revealed a surprising resilience in the job market despite pandemic-related challenges. The currency's upturn also reflects the positive initial impact of Brexit, with traders anticipating a prosperous future for the UK outside of the European Union.

Furthermore, the Bank of England's decision to hold interest rates steady has contributed to the pound's rise. The central bank's statement that it sees no immediate need for negative rates has reassured investors, boosting confidence in the sterling.

On 30 January 1915, England played Scotland in a charity match organised by former England international and Northampton Saints captain Edgar Mobbs. The aim of the match was to raise funds for soldiers affected by the ongoing World War I. This first-of-its-kind event demonstrated the power of sports to unite nations and foster patriotic spirit even in the darkest of times.

During the match, Mobbs' leadership was instrumental in carving a thrilling victory for England and the event marked a significant chapter in the annals of Rugby history. His team displayed exceptional skill, courage, and solidarity – qualities that mirrored those of the soldiers they were playing in honor of.

The charity match was a resounding success, raising substantial funds that were directly channelled towards offering financial aid to the brave soldiers on the frontlines. This game didn't just signify a victory on the rugby field, but also a triumph of human spirit and generosity.

original: The news agency's account was suspended and it advised all tweets should be ignored until further notice. The false message said: "Breaking: Two Explosions in the White House and Barack Obama is injured." US markets were spooked by the tweet; the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 150 points as it was retweeted. On Tuesday evening, the FBI said it was investigating the incident. White House spokesman Jay Carney told reporters soon after the tweet was published that President Obama was fine, and financial markets quickly recovered the lost ground. AP said later: "The @AP twitter account has been hacked. The tweet about an attack at the White House is false." The account was back online on Wednesday. The agency said the attack came after repeated attempts by hackers to steal the passwords of AP journalists, adding that it was working to correct the issue. Spokesman Paul Colford said the wire service had disabled other Twitter accounts following the attack and was working with the microblogging site to investigate the breach. AP reporter

original: Charles Blackman's oil work Women Lovers features two nude women resting on a bed beside a cat. Art broker Mossgreen tried to promote it on Facebook, but the social media network rejected it for "advertising adult products or services". Mossgreen chief executive Paul Summer said the decision was "ridiculous". "This is a very beautiful image that is not overtly sexual in any shape or form," he told the BBC. "It's like going back to the 1950s. It's ridiculous to censor this sort of thing." Facebook said its decision was final, although Mossgreen has since reposted images of the work. "Such ads lead to negative user sentiment and we have zero tolerance towards such advertisements," Facebook said in a message. Last month, a French teacher took Facebook to court after it suspended his account for posting an image of a nude woman painted by 19th Century artist Gustave Courbet. Mr Summer said Women Lovers was expected to sell for more than A$45,000

Hanjin filed for receivership in South Korea last week after attempts to bail out the indebted company failed. Ports have refused to accept Hanjin ships, leaving cargo stranded and causing chaos in global trade. 

Hanjin filed for receivership in South Korea last week after attempts to bail out the indebted company failed. Ports worldwide, from Shanghai to New York, have refused to accept Hanjin's cargo ships due to uncertainty over who would pay docking fees, container storage, and unloading bills. This has led to an unprecedented logjam in the global supply chain.

Hundreds of thousands of containers carrying more than $14 billion worth of goods are stranded at sea, affecting retailers and manufacturers worldwide. The impact is especially severe as preparations for the holiday season are underway, causing considerable disruption and potential losses. 

The collapse of Hanjin, the world's seventh-largest container shipper, has sent shockwaves through the global shipping industry, which is already grappling with low freight rates due to an excess of ships and slowing global trade. The South Korean government's decision not to rescue Hanjin has raised questions about the future of other struggling shippers, potentially triggering

The company behind the abattoir in Haverfordwest, Emcol 2008 Ltd, collapsed in January 2016 with debts of £660,000, leaving local farmers and suppliers in a precarious situation. The firm's sudden closure sent shockwaves through the local economy as it was one of the major employers in the area.

The company's financial woes were traced to a range of factors, including a decline in demand, rising operational costs and increased competition from overseas meat suppliers. The inability to secure sufficient funds for necessary modernization and expansion efforts further exacerbated the situation. 

A significant number of jobs losses were reported, adding to the economic hardship faced by the region. The liquidation process left many local farmers and suppliers unpaid, furthering destabilizing the local agricultural economy.

The fragile piece of wood is all that remains of the Nanteos Cup, a wooden chalice named after the mansion in Aberystwyth, Wales, where it was preserved. The cup, believed to have been made in the 14th century, has been at the center of many a legend, with some even claiming it to be the Holy Grail itself, the cup used by Jesus at the Last Supper.

Despite its diminished state, the relic continues to be revered, with believers attributing healing powers to it. Christopher Kelly, 40, strangled his friend Dorothy Beattie, 51, at her home in Dunoon, Argyll and Bute, Scotland, in a shocking incident that has rocked the quiet community. Kelly, an unemployed man with a history of mental health issues, was reportedly under the influence of alcohol when he attacked Beattie in a heated argument that spiraled out of control.

Police were called to Beattie's home in the early hours of the morning on October 22, following a distress call that reported a violent disturbance. On arriving at the scene, they were met with a chilling sight - Beattie was found lifeless, with clear signs of strangulation.

Kelly was arrested at the scene and later charged with homicide. He has pleaded not guilty, citing self-defence, a claim that local authorities and prosecutors are currently investigating.

The doctors' union had refused to sit down and talk about improving patient care and had spread "misinformation", he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show.

The doctors' union had refused to sit down and talk about improving patient care and had spread "misinformation", he told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show. The union's recent actions have sparked a heated debate about the future of healthcare in the United Kingdom, raising questions about the role of medical professionals in shaping health policies.

According to critics, the refusal by the union to engage in constructive dialogue is hindering efforts to streamline processes, enhance patient satisfaction, and ultimately improve health outcomes. They argue that the union's stance is primarily driven by self-interest, rather than the welfare of patients.

The union, however, has denied these allegations, maintaining that their primary concern is the welfare of both patients and doctors. They argue that they are being unfairly targeted and scapegoated for larger systemic issues within the NHS.

original: The investment is backed by nearly £15m from the Welsh government with production due to start in late 2018. Economy Minister Edwina Hart said the deal would "safeguard more than 750 skilled Welsh jobs for many years". "In a climate of stiff global competitiveness, we have been actively seeking to win a share of this investment for Wales," she said. "Ford's decision to manufacture its new innovative engine here in Wales is a tribute to the reputation of the local management team and the quality and loyalty of the Welsh workforce," she added. The Ford Bridgend plant opened in 1980 and has fought fierce competition to win successive investments in the past worth more than £2.8bn. The company has said its presence supports around 10,000 jobs in south Wales, with 1,860 employed at the plant itself. Ford said technicians based in Essex and Germany had worked together on the design and development of a new fuel-efficient range of

original:
The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates. A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, both under investigation.

The party's 54 sitting MPs are expected to be endorsed as candidates for the upcoming general elections in a move that is being seen as a strategic decision to maintain stability and continuity within the party. This endorsement is expected to boost party morale and also bolster the chances of the party securing its hold in the constituencies they currently represent.

A decision will also be made about the fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, both of whom are under scrutiny for alleged financial discrepancies. The two MPs have been at the center of a controversy that has cast a shadow on the integrity of the party. The decision on their candidacy will be a crucial one as it would signal the party's stand on issues of financial impropriety.

Party insiders are hopeful that the decision will be in favor of the party's reputation and public trust. The upcoming elections will be pivotal in testing the party's resilience amidst these challenges.

A determination will also be made regarding the status of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, who are both under financial investigation.

original: Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes and businesses were shut when major flooding hit Stoke Newington, Blackheath and Islington. Sadiq Khan said people were "rightly furious it appears lessons are not being learnt". Thames Water has said a "full investigation" will take place "to reduce the risk of further disruption". Mr Khan said the "huge damage" caused was "a devastating thing to happen in the run-up to Christmas". "It is right that Thames Water have launched a full investigation, and residents and business must now get full compensation," he said. Director Bob Collington told the BBC the firm had spent "about Â£1bn a year upgrading our network" but "clearly the events of the last few weeks point to the fact that we need to do even more". Some business owners have accused the company of "incompetence" over the floods. Gonen Ozer, who owns two businesses in Stoke Newington, said the mains had been leaking for several days but the water firm had only "patched it up temporarily". original:
Matthew Eteson is on trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, 36, and her ten-year-old daughter, Lauren Thornton. The pair were found dead on a boat owned by Eteson, moored on Lake Windermere in April 2013. It's alleged that their untimely deaths were the result of carbon monoxide poisoning, resulting from a faulty generator Eteson had reportedly installed on the boat.

The prosecution states that Eteson, a gas fitter by trade, had a duty of care towards his partner and her daughter and failed to meet it. They argue that it was his negligence in failing to ensure that the generator was safe that led directly to the tragic deaths. 

Eteson denies the charges, his defense team plans to argue that the deaths were a tragic accident. The trial is expected to last for several weeks, with the outcome having potential legal implications for boat owners nationwide.

Spencer Flower claimed his involvement with a social housing company was not relevant to a debate in 2013 over the future of housing in east Dorset. He defended his actions amid allegations of a conflict of interest. Flower, a member of the Dorset County Council, found himself at the center of controversy when it was revealed that he held a significant stake in a housing company involved in projects in the area.

Critics argued that Flower's affiliation with the company created a conflict between his private interests and his public duties. But Flower insisted that his business interests did not affect his participation in the debate and decision-making process. He stated that he had always been transparent about his business affiliations and had refrained from participating in matters where there might be a conflict.

This incident has ignited a conversation about the need for stricter rules around the disclosure of council members' business interests. It has also raised questions about how local government decisions are made and the extent to which personal interests may influence these decisions.

original:
PC Frances Tilley admitted she had "destroyed her career" after evading payment for a journey between Bristol Temple Meads station and Castle Cary. The incident, which took place last year, has come to light this week after a disciplinary hearing found her guilty of gross misconduct.

Tilley, a police officer with over ten years of service, confessed to travelling without a valid ticket and subsequently providing false information during the formal investigation. This incident has resulted in her dismissal from the Avon and Somerset Police Department.

The panel, chaired by independent legal adviser, Jane Jones, concluded that Tilley's actions were deliberate and constituted a serious breach of the Standards of Professional Behaviour. The decision to dismiss her was unanimous, reflecting the severity of her misconduct. 

In a statement, Tilley expressed remorse for her actions and acknowledged the self-inflicted end of her career. The incident serves as a crucial reminder that police officers, like all individuals, are expected to uphold the law at all times.

original: Regina Hungerford, 56, denied striking a 17-year-old as he listened to music in her class at Merthyr Tydfil College. But a disciplinary panel ruled contact with the pupil was probably made and her conduct had been "unacceptable". On Thursday, the Education Workforce Council imposed the suspension, saying: "The public interest is in favour of her being able to teach again." Mrs Hungerford admitted shouting and slamming a book on the desk of the "provocative and disruptive" teenager as he listened to rap music in her classroom - but always denied hitting his head. She was cleared, on appeal, of a criminal charge for assaulting the pupil during a maths lesson for those with learning difficulties. But in November, a disciplinary panel found, on the balance of probabilities, she had made physical conduct with the pupil on the head or hand. The panel found she had "acted in an inappropriate way" and ruled it was professional misconduct. During the hearing,

original: Mrs Foster said on Wednesday that she wanted to better understand those who love the language. She said she wanted to "listen to and engage with those from the Gaelic Irish background, those without the party political background". Mr Ó Muilleoir said he hoped the meeting would happen soon. "It's a positive move," he said. "Anything that encourages dialogue, that encourages conversations, that encourages increased understanding has to be positive." Stormont's parties have "paused" talks to strike a deal to form an executive until after Easter. The parties have yet to find a deal almost six weeks after the assembly election. One of Sinn Féin's key priorities in the talks is a guarantee that an Irish Language Act will be enacted. In February, Arlene Foster said the DUP would never agree to an Irish Language Act. But she has now said she would meet with "people who genuinely love the Irish language and don't want to use it as a political weapon". original: The 71-year-old won 60.75% of the vote while his nearest rival Kizza Besigye took 35%, the election commission said. Mr Museveni's supporters said his opponents had failed to offer any chance of progress. But Mr Besigye, who is under house arrest, said the results were a "sham", calling on the international community to reject them. "We have just witnessed what must be the most fraudulent electoral process in Uganda," he said in a statement. EU observers have also criticised the poll, saying the governing party had created an "intimidating atmosphere" and that the opposition alleged vote rigging. While praising the "remarkable determination" of Ugandans to vote, EU Chief Observer Eduard Kukan said the governing National Resistance Movement's "domination of the political landscape distorted the fairness of the campaign". The election has been marred by sporadic violence and opposition allegations of electoral fraud, with social media sites and messaging apps blocked. original: An official has told an assembly committee that Cardiff Aviation, which has leased a hangar at St Athan from the administration since 2012, has not paid rent for it to date. The Welsh Government is seeking legal advice over recovering the outstanding debt, a letter says. The company says talks are ongoing. It is not known how much the rent is worth. Mr Dickinson previously told BBC Wales that his firm was losing millions of pounds because of a dispute over landing rights. The Iron Maiden front-man set up Cardiff Aviation in 2012 at RAF St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, leasing a hangar called Twin Peaks from the Welsh Government. Welsh Government small business subsidiary Finance Wales has invested Â£1.6m. A letter from Simon Jones, director of transport and ICT infrastructure, to the assembly's Public Accounts Committee chairman Nick Ramsay said that, "to date", Cardiff Aviation "has not paid any rent for their use of

original: The ban was backed by local authorities in Urumqi, state media reported. The move is the latest in a campaign against Islamic clothing and symbols in the mainly Muslim region. China's government has blamed Uighur militants for several recent attacks - but activists say the violence has been fuelled by Chinese repression. The Uighurs traditionally practice a moderate form of Islam. Recently, though, the influence of stricter forms of the faith from the Gulf and Pakistan has led to more women covering their faces. According to the BBC's Asia Pacific editor, Charles Scanlon, the Chinese authorities regard wearing an Islamic face veil as an act of defiance at a time of growing violence in the region. In August this year, the northern city of Karamay banned men with long beards from boarding buses. Some experts believe such restrictions could backfire at a time when many Uighurs believe their culture is under attack. James Leibold, an expert on China's ethnic
variant_1: Local authorities in Urumqi supported the ban, according to state media reports, as part of an ongoing campaign targeting Islamic clothing and symbols in the predominantly Muslim region. China’s government accuses Uighur militants of recent attacks, though activists argue these acts are a result of Chinese repression. Traditionally, Uighurs follow a moderate Islam, but the recent arrival of stricter religious influences from the Gulf and Pakistan has increased veiling among women. The BBC’s Asia Pacific editor, Charles Scanlon, notes that Chinese officials see Muslim face veils as a form of defiance amid escalating regional violence. In August, Karamay banned men with long beards from buses. Some analysts warn these measures may provoke further unrest, as many Uighurs feel their culture is threatened. James Leibold, an expert on Chinese ethnic issues, has commented on the situation.
variant_2: According to state media, local authorities in Urumqi endorsed a ban that is part of a wider crackdown on Islamic attire and symbols in this mostly Muslim area. The Chinese government holds Uighur militants accountable for recent attacks; however, activists claim that heavy Chinese repression fuels the violence. Uighurs normally observe a moderate Islamic practice, though stricter Gulf and Pakistani interpretations have influenced more women to cover their faces recently. Charles Scanlon of the BBC says the Chinese authorities view the Islamic veil as a sign of resistance amid rising violence. In August, Karamay city prohibited bearded men from using public buses. Experts warn such bans might backfire because many Uighurs feel their cultural identity is under threat. James Leibold, who studies China's ethnic groups, has provided analysis on the issue.
variant_3: State-run media reported that Urumqi’s local officials supported the prohibition, which is part of the latest steps against Islamic clothing and symbols in this predominantly Muslim region. China’s government blames Uighur militants for a number of recent attacks, but activists maintain that Chinese repression is the underlying cause of the violence. Uighurs typically practice moderate Islam, though recently, stricter Islamic influences from the Gulf and Pakistan have caused more women to wear face veils. BBC’s Asia Pacific editor Charles Scanlon states that Chinese authorities consider wearing an Islamic face veil a defiant act during a time of increasing violence. In August, the city of Karamay forbade men with long beards from boarding buses. Some experts suggest these rules might provoke retaliation as many Uighurs believe their culture is being contested. James Leibold specializes in Chinese ethnic matters.
variant_4: Local officials in Urumqi reportedly supported a ban, as noted by state broadcaster coverage, reflecting a broader policy against Islamic clothing and symbols in the mainly Muslim region. The Chinese government implicates Uighur militants in recent violent incidents, though activists attribute the violence to Chinese oppression. Uighurs generally adhere to a moderate version of Islam, but stricter religious practices from Gulf countries and Pakistan have led to an increase in women covering their faces. Charles Scanlon, BBC’s Asia Pacific editor, explains that Chinese authorities perceive the Islamic face veil as a challenge amid escalating violence. original: The button would give Google Search users the option to purchase without needing to visit a separate website. The company's chief business officer, Omid Kordestani, said he wanted to reduce "friction" for users so they buy more things online. Google faces significant competition from Amazon, where many people now begin their search to buy products. "There's going to be a buy button. It's going to be imminent," said Mr Kordestani on stage at the Code Conference in California on Wednesday. The change would make it easier for shoppers to buy products featured in its shopping ads that appear alongside search results. Mr Kordestani also noted that about nine out of 10 purchases are still made offline. He added that the number of location-based searches to help users find something close to them had doubled in the past year. Getting users to buy products as a result of searching is a key revenue earner for Google which currently charges retailers a premium to appear in a prominent position on the results page following a relevant search query. After beating 90,000 other gamers at racing simulation game Gran Turismo, Jann was offered the chance to train as a professional driver. He's now joining Arden Motorsport to compete in the 2014 GP3 series, which is just two rungs below Formula 1. The 22-year-old from Cardiff has also been taken on by Infiniti Red Bull's driver development programme. Jann says winning GT Academy was a huge shock: "I thought I was pretty good because I could beat my friends on my street, but it was the first time trial I ever entered. original: On 30 January 1915, England played Scotland in a charity match organised by former England international and Northampton Saints captain Edgar Mobbs. The aim of the game had been to recruit sportsmen to Mobbs's World War One battalion. The commemorative match will take place on 24 January 2015 at Olney Rugby Club. It will see players from the East Midlands region line up against The 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, while Olney Ladies will face the Army Women's XV. Edgar Mobbs •Born in Northampton in 1882 • He played his early career in Olney and became captain of Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907 •Selected for England in 1909, he scored a try on his debut against Australia and went on to win seven caps •He went from private to battalion commander. fighting in Loos, Somme, Arras and Messines •Mentioned in Despatches twice, he was awarded the Distinguished Service Order •He died while charging a German machine gun during the battle of Passchendale on 31 July 1917 Having retired from rugby in 1913 aged 30, Mobbs was refused an officer's commission when war broke out because of his
variant_1: On 30 January 1915, England faced Scotland in a charity rugby match organised by Edgar Mobbs, a former England player and Northampton Saints captain, aiming to recruit sportsmen for his World War One battalion. The commemorative game will be held on 24 January 2015 at Olney Rugby Club, featuring players from East Midlands against the 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, alongside Olney Ladies versus the Army Women's XV. Edgar Mobbs was born in Northampton in 1882, began his rugby career in Olney, captained Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907, debuted for England in 1909 scoring a try against Australia, earning seven caps. Rising from private to battalion commander, he fought in battles like Loos, Somme, Arras, and Messines, receiving the Distinguished Service Order and two mentions in Despatches. A commemorative match is scheduled for January 24, 2015, at Olney Rugby Club, where East Midlands players will compete against The 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, and Olney Ladies will meet the Army Women's XV. original: The Halle Orchestra wants to open a school in Stoke-on-Trent in 2020, for both primary and secondary pupils. The orchestra will work with an academy trust in setting up the school. John Summers, chief executive of the orchestra, said the project would use music to "raise aspirations" across other academic subjects. The school, proposed with the City Learning Trust, would be part of the free schools programme - and approval for its opening depends on the Department for Education. But the orchestra wants to open the school in September 2020, for seven to 19-year-olds, with the promise of masterclasses from musicians, access to concerts and artists in residence. The intention is for students to spend 40% of their time in specialist music classes, working with the Halle Choir, The Halle Youth Orchestra and Halle for Youth. "The Halle has a huge amount of expertise and experience in working at high level performance, both in terms of instrumental coaching and choral training," said John Summers, chief executive

original:
The 31-year-old tweeted she was turned away from a black cab and told to "find an immigrant" to give her a ride. This alarming incident has sparked a heated conversation on social media about racial bias and discrimination within the transportation industry. The woman, who requested to remain anonymous, shared her shock and disappointment regarding the incident, which took place in Central London on Friday evening.
 
Promoting a wave of outrage and empathy, the tweet has been retweeted over 1,000 times, with many users expressing disgust at the cab driver's blatant display of discrimination. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association, upon learning about the incident, has vowed to investigate the matter, reiterating that such behaviour is completely contrary to their code of conduct. This incident underpins the persistent issue of racial discrimination that continues to plague our society, reminding us of the urgency to address and rectify it. It's a stark reminder that despite strides made in promoting equality, there remains much work to be done.

original: The were 37 crimes recorded in Cromer over the weekend - including the rape of a teenager - with residents linking them to a group of travellers. Suffolk Constabulary said it warned Norfolk Police about the group ahead of its arrival on Friday. Norfolk confirmed it was made aware and said it was reviewing its response. Suffolk officers said they told their Norfolk colleagues about the group after it was issued with a local authority notice to leave Lowestoft on Friday afternoon. The notice had been served after a number of incidents of disturbance in the town. Norfolk confirmed it had been told but said there was "no intelligence to suggest where the group was heading". On Friday, a woman in her late teens was raped at a bus stop in Cadogan Road, near the seafront. Norfolk Police said there was evidence to suggest it could have been linked to the disorder in the town. One man was arrested and released under investigation in connection with the rape. No other arrests have been made. On Saturday night, a BBC reporter was told by a taxi driver that "travellers are rampaging the town",

variant_1: The report from the Institute for Economics and Peace (IEP) stated that the amount equals the combined GDPs of Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, Spain, and the UK. It also highlighted that the gap between the most and least peaceful countries is widening. Iceland remains the most peaceful country globally, while Syria is the least peaceful. Libya experienced the greatest decline in peace during 2014, as per the Australia-based IEP. The Middle East and North Africa have become the world's most violent regions, surpassing South Asia, which held the title in 2013. The report noted that 180,000 people died as a result of conflicts in 2014, up from 49,000 in 2010. Terrorism-related deaths rose by 61% in 2013, reaching nearly 18,000, predominantly in Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Nigeria, and Syria. The IEP estimates that a 10% reduction in global violence could produce £1.43 trillion. IEP CEO Steve Killelea remarked that the most striking discovery was the unequal distribution of peace worldwide.

original: A train travelling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train on platform six just after 15.30 BST on 3 April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch initial findings found the signaller believed there was enough space for both trains on the platform. About 35 people were injured. Read more on this story as it develops throughout the day on our Local Live pages The report said: "Allowing trains to share a platform is known as permissive working, and is allowed for passenger trains using platform six. "The signaller could see the rear of the train from the signal box window and estimated there was enough room for the moving train to fit on the platform. This was not the case." One of the trains was moved to platform six due to passenger lifts being closed for maintenance on alternative platforms, the report said. While approaching Plymouth, the moving train accelerated to about 21 mph and went through a relatively tight, left-hand curve. That is when the driver saw the rear of the stationary train on platform six and was surprised to see it so close to the west end of the platform.

The Rail Accident Investigation Branch's initial findings revealed the signaller believed both trains could fit on the platform. Around 35 people were injured. Continued updates will be available on our Local Live pages. The report explained that "permissive working," allowing trains to share a platform, is authorized for platform six passenger trains. The signaller, viewing from the signal box, estimated there was adequate space for the incoming train alongside the stationary one but this was mistaken. One of the trains was positioned on platform six because passenger lifts on other platforms were undergoing maintenance. Approaching Plymouth, the moving train sped up to about 21 mph navigating a tight left curve, and the driver noticed the rear of the stationary train was unexpectedly close to the west end of the platform.

original: The Republican sought to laugh off the comment, which was preceded by the supporter saying: "We have a problem in this country - it's called Muslims". The comments were made at a campaign rally for Mr Trump in New Hampshire. Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton said his failure to denounce "hateful rhetoric" was "disturbing and wrong". Pointing to his first questioner at the campaign event in Rochester, the billionaire businessman said: "I like this guy." "We have a problem in this country called Muslims," the man said. "We know our current president is one. You know he's not even an American." "We need this question?" Mr Trump said, laughing. "But anyway," the man continued, "we have training camps growing where they want to kill us. That's my question: When can we get rid of them?" Mr Trump failed to clarify that Mr Obama is a Christian American, instead replying that "bad things are happening" and saying he would look into them. Mrs Clinton joined criticism of Mr Trump

The site is believed to contain thousands of copies of a video game called ET The Extra-Terrestrial. A company called Atari made the game in 1982, drawing inspiration from Steven Spielberg's blockbuster of the same name. The site is believed to contain thousands of copies of a video game called ET The Extra-Terrestrial, sealed in a New Mexico landfill. The game's lackluster reception and commercial failure famously led Atari to bury unsold and returned copies, marking a notorious chapter in video gaming history.

Atari, once a giant in the gaming industry, was forced to bury approximately 700,000 cartridges in the Alamogordo landfill following the video game crash of 1983. The ET game earned a reputation as one of the worst games ever due to its confusing gameplay and poor graphics. Its failure, coupled with a general oversaturation of the market, contributed significantly to Atari's financial downfall.

The buried cartridges were unearthed in 2014, confirming rumors that have circulated for years. Now a symbol of the volatile boom and bust cycle in the gaming industry, the ET game serves as a fascinating relic of video gaming's

original:
Transport for London (TfL) is to consult on plans to demand a new English language test, a map-reading assessment, a minimum dress code, and proof of right to work in the UK, from taxi drivers in an effort to improve services and enhance safety for passengers. This comes as an initiative to address a number of issues that have been raised by passengers and the taxi industry.

The proposed tests would be an addition to the already rigorous requirements set by the TfL for taxi drivers, including a topographical test and a medical check. The English language test is aimed to ensure that drivers can effectively communicate with passengers, while the map-reading assessment is designed to improve navigational skills. The introduction of a minimum dress code is to maintain a professional image, whereas the proof of right to work in the UK is a measure to comply with immigration laws.

These changes are expected to raise the standard of service provided by taxi drivers in London and enhance passengers' overall experience. The consultation is due to commence in the coming weeks and will last for three months.

original: The walkout is in protest over the dismissal of two nurses involved in a violent struggle with a patient. Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton were sacked from City Hospital last week, triggering a wave of outrage among their colleagues. The nurses' union argues that the two were merely defending themselves against an aggressive patient, who is known to have a history of violent behavior and mental health issues. They claim that the hospital's management has failed to provide adequate security or safeguards for its staff against such incidents. This dismissal, they contend, sets a dangerous precedent and underscores a lack of support for the staff's safety. The walkout has significantly impacted the hospital operations with many non-emergency procedures being delayed. The management is currently in talks with the nurses' union, hoping to resolve the situation quickly. However, the protesting nurses are firm on their stand and demand a full investigation into the incident before they return to work. They insist that their dismissal was unjust and the administration should address their concerns over workplace safety.

However, of the five candidates vying to become the area's MP, one is totally against it and three admit to having questions over the proposed site. Conservative candidate Michelle Donelan said she could see both sides, but believes the consultation - which has now ended - was inadequate for something that is "dramatically going to change the town forever". original: The new charity will manage the National Heritage Collection, which includes Stonehenge and Dover Castle. The government currently contributes £22m annually towards the collection. The aim is for the charity to eventually become self sufficient. Other powers such as listing buildings will remain government funded. The new official body, which will also advise on planning, has a working name of the National Heritage Protection Service. The new charity will still be called English Heritage and the 420 sites in the National Heritage Collection - which include London's Kenwood House, and Charles Darwin's home in Kent - will remain in public ownership. Government funding for the charity will be tapered down from 2015 eventually to nothing, meaning it will have more freedom than now to generate income from commercial activities and philanthropic donations. Some of the £80m awarded by the government will help to set up the charity so it will be fully operational by

The new entity, provisionally named the National Heritage Protection Service, will also offer planning advice. This charity will retain the name English Heritage, and the 420 sites, including Kenwood House in London and Charles Darwin's residence in Kent, will remain publicly owned. Government funding will be gradually phased out starting from 2015, allowing the charity increased freedom to generate revenue via commercial ventures and philanthropic gifts. Part of the £80 million government grant will support establishing the charity to ensure full operation by its start date.

Among them was a 17-year-old stopped at Sydney airport a fortnight ago, said Immigration Minister Peter Dutton. Mr Dutton said there were increasing concerns about the number of Australian teenagers being radicalized and trying to join extremist groups overseas. The 17-year-old, whose identity has been withheld due to privacy laws, was stopped under Operation Rampart, a joint initiative by the Australian Border Force and the Australian Federal Police, aimed at identifying and deterring individuals from travelling overseas to participate in hostile activities. 

Mr. Dutton warned that extremist groups were actively targeting vulnerable young Australians online, leveraging their sense of isolation or grievances to push radical ideologies. The incident underscores the ongoing threat of homegrown extremism, in a country that has largely been insulated from the global scourge of terrorism.

The Minister urged parents and guardians to keep a vigilant eye on the online activities of their children, raising awareness of the risks associated with radicalisation. He also assured the public that the Government is committed to doing everything in its power to protect Australians from such threats.

original:
Kevin Mcleod's body was found in Wick harbour in February 1997. The 24-year-old's death was treated as accidental, but recent developments have urged a reconsideration of the case. The Mcleod family has long suspected foul play, alleging a cover-up by the local police force.

The Scottish Police Authority (SPA) has now decided to reopen the case, following numerous appeals by the family and the emergence of new evidence. A fresh autopsy report suggests that Mcleod could have suffered internal injuries before drowning, contradicting the initial findings of accidental death by drowning.

The Mcleod family's relentless pursuit for justice and the new autopsy findings have sparked a nationwide conversation about accountability and transparency in law enforcement agencies.

The SPA has expressed its commitment to a comprehensive review of the case. They hope their efforts will provide the family with the answers they have sought for over two decades and potentially bring to light any misconduct or negligence that may have occurred.

original:
Disguised as police, they broke through a fence on Monday evening and broke into the cargo of a Swiss-bound plane to take the stash of precious gems worth millions of dollars. This audacious heist occurred at the Brussels International Airport, shocking authorities and the global community alike. 

The robbers, wearing what appeared to be police uniforms and driving vehicles outfitted with blue flashing lights, pulled off the daring heist with military precision. They moved quickly, using high-powered tools to cut through the perimeter fence, avoiding detection and leaving no one injured. 

The swift and professional operation took the thieves less than twenty minutes, from breach to escape, leaving authorities stunned and empty-handed. The gems were en route from Antwerp, the world's diamond trading hub, to Switzerland when they were intercepted. 

The incident has raised serious concerns about the security of valuable cargo transported by air. Investigations are currently underway, with Interpol and local authorities working together to bring these audacious robbers to justice.

The entire operation lasted less than twenty minutes, from breaking in to escaping, leaving authorities surprised and empty-handed. The gems were being transported from Antwerp, the global diamond trading center, to Switzerland when the heist occurred.

This event has raised major concerns over the security of valuable goods transported by air. Investigations are ongoing, with Interpol and local officials collaborating to capture the daring criminals.

original:
As with last year's parade, only the Orangemen and their 13 notified bands can march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in Belfast during the upcoming annual 12th July demonstrations. This ruling, confirmed by the Parades Commission, follows an unsuccessful appeal by the Carrick Hill Residents Association, who had requested that no loyalist marches be allowed past the Catholic church. 

The decision is seen as a way to avoid clashes and maintain social harmony, following a history of sectarian unrest associated with the parade, which commemorates the 1690 Battle of the Boyne. As part of the ruling, only a single drumbeat will be played by the bands while passing the contentious area. 

Furthermore, the Commission has stipulated that no supporters will be allowed to accompany the march past the church. Both the Orangemen and the residents have been encouraged to continue dialogue to ensure the peaceful passing of the parade.

The ruling is intended to prevent conflicts and promote community peace, considering the parade's history of sectarian tension; it commemorates the 1690 Battle of the Boyne. To reduce provocation, the bands will play only a single drumbeat while passing the sensitive location. Additionally, the Commission has banned supporters from joining the march near the church. Both parties are encouraged to maintain communication to guarantee a peaceful event.

The election commission (Inec) said it hoped to announce the winner on Monday. The UN has praised the poll despite technical hitches, protests, and various challenges that emerged during the voting process. The international body has commended the resilience of voters, election officials, the civil society, and the security services which contributed to the peaceful conduct of the election.

While acknowledging the technical issues and protests that were reported in certain areas, the UN has hailed the general consensus of commitment and enthusiasm demonstrated by the citizenry towards the democratic process. The widespread voter participation and the peaceful atmosphere under which the election was conducted reflect the maturity of the nation's democracy.

However, the UN emphasized the need for authorities to thoroughly investigate reported cases of electoral misconduct and to ensure that those responsible are held accountable. It also urged all parties to exercise patience as the Inec continues to tally the results, and to maintain the peace that has so far characterized the election process.

original: Media playback is not supported on this device Fraser, the world number 90, hit nine birdies to finish with an eight under par 63, three shots ahead of the field. More than half of the men's world's top 10 pulled out of competing at Rio 2016, citing the Zika virus. Briton Justin Rose, one of a group on four under, hit the first ever Olympic hole-in-one on the par-three fourth. "There is always an element of luck but you could chalk it up as a good hole-in-one," said Rose. "I won a car that time [his last hole-in-one] but this is definitely better, better bragging rights. When you are the first to do something no one can take that away from you. That was definitely a cool moment." Newly crowned Open champion Henrik Stenson is tied for second with Canada's Graham Delaet on five under. Rose is one of five men tied for fourth on four under; along with Belgium's Thomas Pieters, Gregory Bourdy of France, Alex Cejka of Germany and Spain's Rafael Cabrera Bello. Rachel Miller has paid "brokers" up to £7,500 a time to free sex slaves. She travelled to parts of southern Asia, risking her life on an audacious mission to liberate women and children ensnared in the brutal world of human trafficking. 

This bold British woman, moved by the horrific stories of sexual exploitation, chose to dedicate her life to combat this heinous crime. Operating under constant danger, she put her safety on the line to negotiate with ruthless traffickers. 

Her mission, although fraught with peril, has led to the successful rescue of hundreds of victims. Each individual saved is a testament to Miller's courage and perseverance in the face of a grotesque industry that abuses the vulnerable.

Despite the risks, Miller continues her tireless work, raising awareness about human trafficking, and urging global authorities to intensify their efforts to end this modern-day slavery. This courageous woman's story is a powerful reminder that one person's determination can indeed make a world of difference.

original: Unemployment fell to 1.69 million between January and March, down 2,000 from the previous quarter. The jobless rate remained at 5.1%, the ONS said. There were 31.58 million people in work, up 44,000 from the previous quarter. That took the employment rate to a record high of 74.2%. But the number of job vacancies dropped by 18,000 to 745,000, the ONS added, marking the first fall for almost a year. David Freeman, a senior statistician at the ONS, said: "The employment rate has hit another record high, but this time the increase is quite modest. "With unemployment very little changed, that is further evidence the jobs market could be cooling off." Average earnings including bonuses rose 2% from a year earlier, up from 1.9% in the three months to February. The ONS said the timing of bonuses this year had affected the rise in total earnings. Excluding bonuses, earnings rose by 2.1% year-on-year in the three months to March, down from 2.2% in the three months to February. The number

Evha Jannath, 11, was on a school trip on Tuesday when she fell from a circular boat on Splash Canyon at Drayton Manor Theme Park. A tragic incident unfolded on Tuesday when Evha Jannath, an 11-year-old girl, fell from a circular boat on Splash Canyon during a school trip at Drayton Manor Theme Park. The Bright Start Academy pupil from Leicester was airlifted to Birmingham Children's Hospital, but unfortunately succumbed to her injuries. 

The incident has sent shockwaves through the community, and has put a spotlight on safety measures in amusement parks. Jannath was on a water ride at the park, which is a popular attraction for families and school groups. 

Her school released a statement expressing their grief over the tragic loss of a promising student and extended their condolences to her family. Drayton Manor Theme Park is currently closed for investigations, with park officials working closely with safety experts and local authorities to determine the exact circumstances that led to this terrible event. The incident has sparked a nationwide conversation about the adequacy of current amusement park safety standards.

NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) has stated that blood group O negative is crucial, as it can be used for patients with other blood types, making it especially valuable in emergency situations. NHSBT, the agency responsible for ensuring a safe and sufficient supply of blood in the UK, is currently facing an urgent appeal for O negative donors to come forward following a sharp decrease in donations.

According to the NHSBT, the reserves of O negative blood have fallen below the preferred minimum of three days' worth. The group A & O negative are universal donors, and their blood can be used in any patient, making it a vital resource in urgent or emergency care when there may not be time to determine a patient's blood group.

In response to the ongoing crisis, NHSBT is urging healthy individuals, particularly those with O negative blood type, to consider donating blood urgently. The process is quick, easy, and can potentially save lives. Every donation can help or save up to three lives,

The interactive display can replicate the phone's touch screen, a full-size computer keyboard or even piano keys. The laser projector can also be used to transfer various interfaces onto tabletops, walls, or even your own hand. 

This groundbreaking technology is paving the way for a new era of interactivity, propelling us towards a future where physical devices may become obsolete. The practical applications are endless, from providing musicians with portable, easily customizable instruments to offering a more immersive and flexible workspace for professionals.

The laser projector works by emitting a grid of infrared beams. When the user interacts with the projected interface, the beams are interrupted, and the system can calculate the exact location of the interaction. For instance, each faux piano key or button pressed on a projected keyboard can correspond to a specific note or command.

Albeit still in its early stages, this technology has the potential to revolutionize our interaction with digital media. It promises to make our everyday tasks more efficient, flexible, and remarkably futuristic. The future

original: The Lyndhurst Park Hotel, once linked to smuggling, was visited by Treasure Island author Robert Louis Stevenson. Developer PegasusLife wants to replace it with 74 pensioner flats. Opponents insist the unlisted building is historically significant and an influx of elderly residents would put pressure on services in the village. The plans to be considered by the National Park Authority (NPA) are open for consultation until early January. Originally named, Glasshayes House, the mansion house on the edge of Lyndhurst was built in the early 19th Century as a private home for railway entrepreneur Charles Castleman. Along with Louis Stevenson, its notable historical guests included Lord Carnarvon of Highclere Castle. It later became the Grand Hotel, and then the Lyndhurst Park Hotel. original: The firm is accused of giving large donations to non-profit foundations operated by Choi Soon-sil, a close confidante of Ms Park. The donations were allegedly given in exchange for political support of a controversial merger. Ms Choi has been charged with coercion and attempted fraud. According to South Korea's Yonhap news agency, Choi Gee-sung, a Samsung vice chairman, and Chang Choong-ki, a president at the group, were being interviewed on Monday by special prosecutors about the corruption allegations. It was reported the pair were being treated as witnesses, rather than being suspected of any wrongdoing. The claims circle around a merger between the electronics giant's construction arm, Samsung C&T, and an affiliate firm, Cheil Industries. The deal went through despite significant opposition from shareholders, who said it would hurt minority shareholders while benefiting the family of Samsung's group owner Lee Kun-hee. South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS), which owns stakes in both companies, sealed the deal by voting in favour of it and the head of the NPS has since been arrested. But prosecutors also allege that Samsung gave â‚¬2.8m euros ($3.1m; Â£2.5m) to a company

The controversy involves a merger between Samsung's construction unit, Samsung C&T, and affiliate Cheil Industries. Despite strong shareholder opposition, claiming harm to minority investors and benefit to Samsung's owner Lee Kun-hee's family, the deal proceeded. South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS), a stakeholder in both firms, voted in favor; its head has since been arrested. Prosecutors also claim Samsung gave €2.8 million ($3.1 million; £2.5 million) to a company.

original:
The ban was backed by local authorities in Urumqi, state media reported. The move is the latest in a campaign against Islamic clothing and symbols in the region. The regulation has stirred international controversy, with human rights advocates voicing their concerns over the potential infringement on individual religious freedoms. 

The local government in Urumqi, the capital city of Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, has argued that the ban seeks to counteract extremism and maintain social harmony. They insist it is not an attempt to suppress the Islamic faith, but rather a measure to prevent the spread of radical ideologies. The ban includes items such as the burqa, a full-body veil worn by some Muslim women, and "jilbabs," outer garments covering the body.

Critics, however, argue that the ban is a symptom of the broader issue of religious discrimination, particularly against the Uyghur Muslim minority. They warn against the potential for increased social alienation and unrest as a result of such measures

original: The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The volcano, located 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant, is also close to Kagoshima, a city of 600,000. Sakurajima's last deadly eruption was in 1914, when 58 people died. The Japanese archipelago, which sits on the Pacific "Ring of fire", has more than 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima regularly spews ash and there are many small explosions there each year, with the latest eruption being in February. It is closely monitored by Japanese authorities and one of two volcanoes at Level 3 out of 5 levels in Japan's volcanic warning system, which means that people are warned not to to approach the volcano. "The 1914 eruption measured about 1.5km cubed in volume," said the study's lead author Dr James Hickey, who has now joined the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines. "From our data we
