original: Helen Bailey, 51, was found dead in a cess pit at her house in Royston, Hertfordshire, in July 2016. She had not been seen since 11 April. Ian Stewart, her fiance, denies murder. Edward Farmer initially told St Albans Crown Court he saw her in a car in Broadstairs, Kent, between mid-April and June, but later admitted the sighting could have been weeks earlier. The jury heard he claimed to have seen Ms Bailey on Charlotte Street, near to her holiday home in the town, "driving what looked to be a Range Rover or that type of 4x4, a dark colour". He said Ms Bailey was by herself, despite defence claims she had been kidnapped by two violent men who had taken her to Broadstairs. When questioned about the date of the alleged sighting, Mr Farmer said it was "about five, maybe six weeks prior to the police interview [on 13 July]". Ms Bailey

original: A report from British Marine, which represents the leisure, superyacht and small commercial marine industry, said superyacht revenues for the year to date have been skyrocketing. Amid the ongoing pandemic, the superyacht sector is seeing unprecedented growth, demonstrating a 24% increase in revenues compared to the previous year. The luxury sector is experiencing a significant boom, fueled by a surge in demand from high-net-worth individuals seeking safe, social-distanced leisure options. Despite economic uncertainties, the industry has shown resilience, with an increasing number of new build orders and charter bookings. The report also highlights the UK's growing prominence in the global superyacht market, with the country's highly skilled workforce and exceptional craftsmanship being key drivers for the industry's success. This surge showcases the strength and adaptability of the marine industry, even amidst challenging times, contributing significantly to the nation's economy while upholding the highest levels of luxury and exclusivity.

original: Ben Butler met a psychologist in 2004 after assaulting a man in a nightclub. Dr Tim Green wrote Mr Butler found it "difficult to control his violence when he felt humiliated" and "historically would become angry and punch people". The 36-year-old denies murdering six-year-old Ellie at their home in Sutton, south west London, in October 2013. Dr Green interviewed Mr Butler over four hours after he pleaded guilty to assaulting a man in Kingston upon Thames 12 years ago, the Old Bailey heard. Prosecutor Ed Brown QC read sections of the report in which Dr Green noted Mr Butler was "co-operative" and answered questions "frankly". Dr Green wrote: "He stated that he had in the past hoped that situations might present themselves where he could engage in violence. "He believed that violence could help him improve his mood when he was upset. Historically he would become angry and punch people. "He was adamant he had never hit anybody without a reason. original: The Lyndhurst Park Hotel, once linked to smuggling, was visited by Treasure Island author Robert Louis Stevenson. Developer PegasusLife wants to replace it with a modern, state-of-the-art retirement complex. The proposal includes 74 apartments and a host of luxurious amenities for residents to enjoy. However, the plan has sparked widespread controversy among local residents and historians, due to the hotel's iconic status and its cultural importance as a former haunt of Stevenson. They argue that the building holds significant historic value and should be preserved rather than demolished. The hotel, which has stood empty since 2014, was reportedly a hub for smugglers in the 18th century, and it is claimed Stevenson, famed for his adventure novels, stayed there while writing 'Treasure Island'. Despite the backlash, PegasusLife maintains that their proposal will bring a much-needed boost to the local economy through job creation and increased tourism. The final decision is awaited from the local council.

original: Geoffrey Stewart, 74, of Dumfries, was one of three men in their 60s and 70s who went missing in the Southern Uplands on Tuesday. Police said he died late on Wednesday night at Dumfries and Galloway Royal Infirmary. George Crosbie, 73, also from Dumfries, died earlier on Wednesday. A third man, Bobby Thomson, 64, remains in hospital. A statement from Mr Stewart's family said: "Our family would like to extend our love and thoughts to the families involved at this very sad and tragic time. "Sincere gratitude and appreciation goes out to all the services involved in the rescue efforts and hospital staff at Dumfries and Galloway Royal Infirmary." The men failed to return from a walk in the hills at Durisdeer on Tuesday. Sixteen members of Moffat Mountain Rescue team (MRT) and two search and rescue dogs combed the hills for the men until the early hours of Wednesday. However the search was stood down amid heavy rain, snow, high winds and poor visibility. When it

The veteran footballer, who has previously played in European leagues, brought a wealth of experience and skill to Atletico Kolkata. His leadership on and off the field played a pivotal role in guiding the team to the playoffs this season. 

Despite his age, the midfielder demonstrated his physical prowess, maintaining consistency throughout the season. His tactical acumen was particularly praised, giving Atletico Kolkata a crucial edge in key moments of their games.

While the player's future is still under speculation, sources inside the club suggest that they would be keen on retaining him for another season. original: The Starman's swansong, Blackstar, spent a third week at number one, with Best of Bowie, Hunky Dory and Ziggy Stardust all in the Top 10. Adele remained at two, while Suede, who were heavily inspired by Bowie, scored the highest new entry at number six. Rihanna's new album, Anti, did not chart after its release on Thursday. The record was considered ineligible as it was initially given away via the streaming music site Tidal. Official chart company rules state that free downloads do not count towards the top 40. However, the Bajan star did score a new entry in the singles chart. Work, her duet with Drake, made its first appearance at 13 after just 48 hours on sale. The highest new entry, at three, is a dance version of Tracy Chapman's Fast Car by London-based producer Jonas Blue. His tropical-flavoured remake, which features vocals by singer

original: Midfielder Arteta, 32, had a bony spur removed from his left ankle, which the club said has been causing him "significant discomfort" for months. Defender Debuchy, who just returned from three months out with an ankle injury, had an operation on a shoulder he dislocated in the win over Stoke. Boss Arsene Wenger described Debuchy's injury on Sunday as "unbelievable". "It's very unfortunate," said the Frenchman. "It's unbelievable because he's had two surgeries in the same season. He just came back, he played seven games and he's out again." Debuchy has played just 14 times since signing from Newcastle in July in a deal worth a reported £12m. With Kieran Gibbs recovering from an inflamed heel, 19-year-old Hector Bellerin or Calum Chambers may deputise against Manchester City on Sunday. original:
Meanwhile, Burundian police said they had arrested two foreign journalists who were reporting on armed groups. Violence in the country began last April, when President Pierre Nkurunziza announced his controversial bid for a third term. This sparked a series of protests and a failed coup attempt, leading to the death of over 400 people and displacing more than 240,000.

These arrests mark a deepening crisis for freedom of press in Burundi, a nation already beleaguered with political and societal unrest. The journalists, whose identities have not yet been released, were reportedly taken into custody while on assignment, capturing the turbulent situation in the capital, Bujumbura.

International press groups and human rights organizations have protested against the arrests, calling for the immediate release of the journalists and urging the Burundian government to respect press freedom and human rights. The arrest of journalists not only undermines the principles of free press, but also obstructs the world's understanding of the crises that Burundi

Despite ongoing political turmoil, the detained journalists were working in Bujumbura to report on the unrest. Their identities remain confidential. original: Rachel Miller has paid "brokers" up to Â£7,500 a time to free sex slaves. She travelled to parts of southern Turkey this summer that the Foreign Office had declared no-go zones. But the recent coup attempt in Turkey means she cannot work "under the radar" any longer, she said. Ms Miller, 40, a mother-of-three from Cinderhill in Nottingham, said her Kurdish husband supported her work but she did not always tell him the full story until after she had returned. "I don't deal directly with the slavers - but I deal with a broker who has contacted a family that wants to free their child from slavery," she said. "He says I can get your daughter but it will cost - it can cost up to $10,000."
